reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRoad Redemption is a totally f&%$ing mad Road Rash update on the Unity engine. Still in Early Access at the time of writing, while the game looks a little rough around the edges it is still mightily playable. Cars, trucks and bikes zoom and whizz in every f&%$ing direction, ragdolls fly through the air with the slightest of ease and all manner of blunt instruments are swung at your head from every side. Bludgeoning motorcycle cops and rival gang bikers is tremendously satisfiying and the actual racing physics is entirely satisfactory. Great stuff.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't had this much fun playing a video game in a long time.  If you like Road Rash, you'll love this!

PROS
+ Good graphics and sound
+ Mostly tight controls leave you fully in charge of your racer
+ Varied weapon types including guns, tazers, and explosives
+ Temporary boosts and permanent upgrade system keeps things engaging
+ Multiple mission types including Destroy Enemies, Attract Police, and Race
+ Chaotic gameplay leads to some hilarious and exciting moments
+ It's a BLAST!

CONS
- Selection of bikes and racers limited
- Courses, while randomized and fun, aren't memorable (except one colorful shocker!)
- Rooftop level infuriates (until you get the hang of it)
- Gang system is not really utilized
- Campaign could use more substance (ranking system, story, etc.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Its probably best if this is gotten out of the way from the beginning... Road Rash!  If there is any game that Road Redemption can be compared to, it's Road Rash.

At this point of the development, the game is pretty simple.  The player begins a campaign and enjoys some intense motorcycle action.  There is no real story at this time, and the multiplayer is still to come, but what the game already offers is well made.  The bugs are minimal, the game has never crashed, and it is very playable.

The combat requires some work to get the timing right.  Each melee weapon has a different attack range and speed that it is swung, not to mention the satisfying sound that some of them make.  The sledgehammer is boss.  The ranged weapons are really powerful, but can cause a distraction while aiming that can lead to a crash.  Fighting against AI is fun and good practice, but this game could be crazy with multiplayer!

Speaking of the AI, the npc cars may as well be tanks!  Some are pretty mundane and cruse down the road, but others are out for destruction and do not follow the laws of physics -- at all!  They make the rules as they plow through incoming cars without a budge.

The game is pretty bare bones right now, but the devs have a really solid foundation to work with and some of the ideas that are implemented in this game are a lot of fun, but there is some fine tuning that needs to be done before the multiplayer can be engaged.  The time spent has been extremely enjoyable -- nostalgia -- better than many finished titles of this price.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=323943171

Suddenly i am taken back to my youth, hunched over an old arcade console spewing 20c coins into the machine to keep my dream alive.
This game is a must for any old school racer who needs a nostalgia injection administered by a guy on a bike weilding a baseball bat, Gameplay is nice. smooth, still some work to be done with the AI i believe.

Most importantly the Dev who is working on this release is actively patching and updating daily, i have already spoken to him in regards to some of the game mechanics and my input was welcomed and appreciated.

I am yet to try co-op or multiplayer as none of my friends own this release yet, but i have no doubt it will be smooth, and any issues that are found will be fixed promptly

Giving this game 8/10, for an indie release especially, this game is fantastic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

By far the most payoff for an early access game that I've had. It's wonderfully arcade-ish while still having fluid, physics-based action. The shooting is nice, the melee is nice (although I wish you could HOLD an attack and charge it up and let go when you're ready like in Road Rash!

The weapon selections are neat, the game modes are varied and fun - and there's a level-up system that doesn't take very long to max out (I just maxed mine out on the first day), but the replay value is immense.

Turbo boosts, grappling hooks, jump jets??? It's exactly as fun as it sounds. Which, if you're me, is a lot.

Very much like road rash on 3d crack, but in a good way. Nice interface, good graphics, and when you beat the campaign you get the option to call the developer himself and tell him what you think of the game!

Definitely not a purchase you'll regret if you like the idea of a crazy action-packed spiritual successor to Road Rash.

On the rooftop levels, you basically get to be batman on a motorcycle. Once you get the hang of using the jump jets, boost and grappling hook in combination with each other, you can seriously stay airborn for a LONG time. You'll feel like a total pimp the first time you use the grappling hook to swing around a 90 degree turn while airborn.

I highly recommend this game for people who like fun.

I had this one sitting in my wishlist for a while. Excited by the idea of a modern return and spiritual successor to Road Rash. I waited for a price drop on this one as it is early access before purchase. ( As I always do )

Combat

reviewText:
Early Access Review

- Early Access Review -

This game is a love-letter to the Road Rash series. Even in its current state, if you have any fond nostalgia for those games, you owe it to your inner-child to pick this title up.

Currently, the game is limited to a campaign mode of progressive areas and difficulty. There is racing against the timer, racing against a specific rival gang, night driving, icy tracks, cars raining down from the sky, police chases, exploding vehicles, rooftop racing... and I enjoyed every satisfying slash and crash that forcibly de-seated my fellow racers as I burned past them. Every time you die, all of your XP earned through that play-through can be spent on permanent player upgrades, adding to your health, damage, weapon durability, ammuntion, etc... so on each successive run, you'll have even more of an edge on your side.

The game plays fast and feels fast with little stuttering (running on an i3 processor with a GTX 640 Nvidia card), though there are instances of SUDDENLY-CARS, because the draw distance seems a little close to your bike. The way the bikes handle feels instinctive (using an x360 controller), and the button layout is workable... though not perfect. The ability to remap the keys isn't currently implemented, but it is one of the features on the list to be added. Based on the level of polish the game already has, this is definitely not a project with sloppy devs... I would highly believe that patches, new game modes, and features are en route.

For downsides, though... with only one current play-mode, the game will grow repetitive after a while. The AI routines of the opponent riders is somewhat predictable, and once you learn the timing of the weapon swings, they frequently fall for a basic swerve-n-strike pattern. There are plenty of weapons to experiment with, including the grappling hook which is a blast to use, but its still an issue of slowly becoming familiar and then boring. There is no automatic lock-on for any firing weapon... that takes a while to get used to, as your ability to aim is also your camera control... perfect for the shotgun, but very tricky for the uzi. The roads themselves are far more lethal than the other riders, and while this is an excellent thing, currently specific conditions like the raining cars can make those races VERY difficult, and can completely shut down a run.

Its an awesome thing to see, mind you... driving through a downpour of debris, but that feature needs to be scaled back enough to be able to actually navigate through the falling wrecks.

Multiplayer is a listed feature of the game. That would seriously increase this game's replayability factor, and it would be AWESOME to be able to race against other players with this engine, but currently that feature isn't available.

All that said, I still HIGHLY recommend this game in its current state. Its very playable, low on the glitches, a TON of fun, and I have full confidence that upcoming features and fixes will just make this even more enjoyable of an experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want this game to be good, but right now I can't recommend.  First the physics kinda suck.  The bikes have too much grip; theres usually not a reason to let up off the gas in a turn which is not how motorcycles work.  Flat out on the gas the whole race isnt racing at all and it degenterates this game into just another hussle for turbo, which then becomes the only reason to actually fight another racer.  You dont have to hold off your pole position like in Road Rash if you can turbo hop from one random spawned un-ranked racer to the next.  Which gets boring quick.  Also lame when a mob of un ranked, like not in any place 1st-15th, all hit you at once and the games over.  And all your stuffs gone.  No bike upgrades except for one skill that doesnt really feel like it does anything.  The Semi is a cool idea but its broken, goes way to fast and then consistently runs you over after you defeat it.  Also theres to many times where hiting a car or telephone pole head on just stops you or instantly makes you travel in reverse without falling off the bike.  All the bikes feel about the same, they just change the difficulty.  Which I don't like.  There shouldnt be a difficulty.  It should be about racing and fighting/positioning skills, getting money to get better weapons and bikes so you can win those harder races.  You cant steal weapons which was one of the best things about the original road rash games.  You just pick it up automatically after you kill the person that had it.  I WANT to have that crowbar that I stole from Jorg in the second race.  It has sentimental value.  Also the AI dont get vindictive like they would in Road Rash. The penalty for death is to high, I cant choose the level I go next, The bikes make no noise, theres NO PEDESTRIANS to run over or cross traffic.

Just ... Just make it like Road Rash.

Take out the counters, weapon durability, how kicks make you completely stunned instead of forcing your to try to regain control, Fix the Physics so you actually have to race, maybe make traction loss a thing, and take out turbo except on maybe the last 3 bikes.  Also the weapon system is kinda lame. I die all the time trying to switch weapons, because to do so requires you to take your thumb off the steering.  Shootings is meh... Needs to be easier to switch weapons or shoot to the side.

Oh another thing.  Study the actuall bike market right now, particularly the technology that exists, like traction control, electronic variable susspension, sproket changes, tire compound...Every bike enthusiast I know is a gear head and if you can't drool over that next upgrade theres no incentive.  I want to save up the 20k to buy that BMW S1000 HR or w/e if is with the traction and suspension control that basically handles everything about cornering except braking an leaning.  I don't like racing just for XP  points.

I had high hopes for this, but as it stands, I really regret my purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I grew up playing the ever living ♥♥♥♥ out of Road Rash, and this game is looking very promising!

The game is currently being developed and you should definitely keep that in mind if you consider purchasing. The game, so far, is not a finished game. That doesn't mean you shouldn't buy it in early access, it just means you should know what to expect. Right now the devs promise a 10-15 hour experience, and that is precisely what they deliver. 10-15 hours of sheer fun is to be had racing, slicing, bashing and shooting opponents with anything from pipewrenches to medieval axes, to handguns to grenade launchers. Nothing says ♥♥♥♥ you like Father Christmas bashing someone's head in with a giant candy cane.

The game is not without its flaws, though. As is, the levels get rather stale after a while, there is hardly any diversity in bikes and riders, the music is not as iconic as the original Road Rash, the skill tree is very lineair, boring, and doesn't allow for experimentation, and the buyable in-campaign upgrades are 50% ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t filler stuff.

I'm sure a lot of that will be adressed by the devs before the game is released. I think the game is great so far, and does the original Road Rash justice. I've had a blast, and I know you will too. I'm eagerly awaiting how this game will turn out. In the mean time, just enjoy the ride!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At this point in time (2/18/16) the game is still in its Early Access phase, and I've tried to not review it until total completion, but I've had it in my library long enough and have played it enough times to be confident that my opinion of it will not change in any notable way for the worse. That being said, it's crazy-stupid-awesome how fun this game is. As it stands in its development, there is no story to speak of, which includes dialogue, cutscene's or character names (with the exception of a handful of extra-powered baddies). And as someone who usually finds story-telling and character-development a very important part of the games he plays, I couldn't care less. You drive down long highways on a motorcycle and kill rivals with an assortment of guns, swords, and blunt objects. Not to mention sticky packs of C4 charges. The continuous swarm of enemies that seem to be procedurally spawned (though I don't know for certain) make it unlikely you'll every run out of things to hit, or things to hit with. Though if you do, you can always kick at their wheels or grab them and steer them into oncoming traffic. But what makes the game endearing is the immensly satisfying instant gratification of the gameplay; you never hear people in the arcade playing House of the Dead complain about where all these monsters came from or who the main villain is because it doesn't make it any more fun to continuously blast zombies in the head.

But what if you're no good? Like, not at ALL? It barely matters. The system of upgrades, which utilizes both use this til you die" items as well as "You're dead now? Tune up your bike and try again" items ensures that even an embarrassingly awful defeat at the hands of a sub boss in the second level will still give you a slightly better chance next time.

I've been playing this title since shortly after its release to the Steam community
date: and I have not once regretted the decision. The easy-to-pickup nature of the best arcade racing games
recommended: touch of self-aware humor of GTA3
hoursPlayed: and the immensely satisfying carnage of Twisted Metal 2 make Road Redemption a title you're sure to come back to over and over again. If you don't already have a game in your library for instant catharsis
voteText: Road Redemption is as good a suggestion as any.\n\nA billion stars (out of a billion and six)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is pretty decent. It has issues true, but overall it's a decent package if you're looking for a Road Rash experience.

Pros:

- Good weapon variety
- Several different riders
- Riding feels decent at speed and speed effect is good
- Hitting riders with melee weapons feels really good and solid

Cons:

- approximately 1/4 of the Weapons are severely underpowered in later levels
- Riding feels wonky and controls weird at low speeds
- Repetetive
- Rooftop levels are weird

Long story short, if you liked Road Rash back in the day there's a good chance you'll like Road Redemption. Certain elements of the game feel really good and solid while others are obviously a little lacking.

$20 really isn't too bad but it might be a bit much given the repetitive nature of the game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hesitantly recommend this game. Ultimately it's fun, and it'll give you a (somewhat) modern(ish) version of road rash. But be warned that it does lack a certain level of polish, and is a definite sale-purchase.

In terms of presentation, graphics and audio, you're looking at something (very) comparible to FlatOut 2 (2006). As it's an arcade style racer (sort of) it kind of gets away with it, but it is a shame. Nobody is looking for Assetto Corsa level of fidelity, but a half decent soundtrack and a UI that wasn't pulled from a Robot Wars DVD menu would be nice.

But it's fun. It's a fun game.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Within about 6 1/2 hours (I've clocked 5.9 but played a bit in offline mode), I've completed the campaign, campaign+ mode, and managed to come first on all the quick races. I haven't played anything like this game before, it's quite fun, though occasionally frustrating. I found it tricky at first and must have failed the campaign at least four or five times before I managed to complete it, but I breezed through the campaign+ mode first try and didn't find many parts of that to be particularly difficult, so my main concern is whether the leveling/upgrade system slowly takes the real challenge out of the game. There isn't an awful lot of content for the £15 price tag, but I enjoyed what I played and I'm looking forward to seeing where this game goes, so I would recommend it.

Also, the devs openly give out their phone number in the game. I don't know if it's legit, but that's pretty neat.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a great throwback to the old Road Rash series of games that I first enjoyed on the 3DO.  I'm a big fan of Road Redemption as it is right now, and I've played through the current campaign and NG+ modes.  The variety of levels is enjoyable, and the way they have designed a seperation between permanent skills and play-through purchases feels good.

However, the controls can feel a little unforgiving at times, and once you've played the limited number of modes there's not much more to experience other than slightly different maps, and varying degrees of difficulty.

I'm looking forward to seeing this game improve and get more content. I wouldn't have purchased it at full price for where it at's currently, but I got it at 50% off and feel like that was about right for the time I've spent going through the content.

While I used to LIKE, not love, Road Rash back in the day, this game is the hardest piece of ♥♥♥♥ I've come across due to the A.I. always catching up to me, matching my speed and then meleeing the ♥♥♥♥ out of me until we all:

Overall, I'd say wait until it has a full release, read some reviews after that, and then maybe try to find a way to play it, maybe from a friend that has it or something, then if you like it, buy it. I am currently regretting this purchase.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIt's not perfect(and since it's still in early access, that's to be expected anyway), but it is a lot of fun, and the devs seem committed to getting updates done. If the idea of Road Rash meets rogue-like appeals to you, then you'll probably enjoy this game. The physics are appropriately arcade-y, and the combat feels satisfyingly brutal. It can be frustratingly difficult at times, especially if you're like me and don't have great twitch reflexes, but it's still great to play in short bursts. My only major complaint is with the mission variety. Nine times out of ten, I end up with a race. The races are fun, but I'd like a more even distribution with the more violence-oriented goals.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

September 20 - I decided to go on a joy ride.

September 21 - I reached a gasoline station and gassed my motorcycle. From the road there were guys in leather jacket shouting, and causing chaos while riding their motorcycle at full speed. Red flag but I continued my journey anyway.

September 21 / Night - I decided to speed the night on the road so I built a camp fire near the river.

September 22 - I met a trucker, nice guy who gave me some directions.

September 22 / Night - I decided not to spend another night on the road and I was eager to reach the next town so I continued my journey. It was creepy and I was travelling on Route 23 when suddenly out of nowhere some dude knocked me with a baseball bat. I crashed and was rendered unconscious.

September 23 - So I woke up and from the road there were a bunch of dudes on motorcycle whacking each other so I decided to take the 'off road'. I trekked through the mountains to reach my goal and I reached the next town.

To be continued...

I have played a similar game on the PSX a decade before. It's a racing game about polygon bashing each other before reaching the goal.

Now fast track to 2015.

Honestly there's not much of this type of game on Steam so it's a total bliss to see this game here. Instead of polygons, we now have a realistic dudes bashing each other while keeping your motorcycle stable and avoiding traffic.

To be continued...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Like Road Rash 64, but bigger, better, and more surreal. Racing motorcycles, equipment, xp, hitting people with pipes, blowing up trucks with c4, etc. etc. The controls are still a little wobbly for keyboard, guns are kinda hard to aim on the steam controller, but it's got local multiplayer that brings the 1990s back. The single player is enjoyable too, but multiplayer is where the most value is.

It's early access and the devs are committed to the game, easy to contact (as in, their phone number is in the game and they will actually pick up and talk to you), and the core gameplay is great.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI bought this while on sale for $8.  I would gladly buy again at full price.  Playing local coop with my daugther thirty minutes into the game (almost 10) she was say that this is one of the best games ever.  Not sure about that part yet but it certainly is a fun game and has the makings to be a very good game with further love and development by the developers.  It was certainly even with only an hour spent so far worth the money.   Is it rough around the edges?  Very.  Graphically it isn't anything to write home about.  Sound wise I can't say as we didn't have the sound playing.  I am not much on sound effects anyway so I usually am not big on reviewing that side of games.  I love soundtracks but only when I am playing OST burnt to CDs in my car.  Anyway to me this type of game is all about is it fun.  This isn't a game that is meant to be complex looking so the graphics really aren't that big of deal to me.  They are smooth for the most part so that is what I care about.  There are a few clipping issues that I am sure will get worked out.  Texture wise this isn't meant to be a game you are going to stop and look at the roses anyway.     Control wise I played via keyboard and my daughter via offical 360 controller.  We have a second 360 contoller but I was too lazy to hook up so I am going on her word about the contoller controls but she didn't seem to have any real problems with them.   The keyboard controls using the default WASD/Keyboard controls were fair but had some drift in them.  I am sure the developers will tighten up the controls as game development goes along so I am not too worried about that.   However contol in this type of game is one of the bigger issues worth looking at so if you are wondering as far as July 5th, 2015 at least as far as keyboard controls I can say that the bikes do control a floaty" that I would like.   Once again this is a EA title and I am sure this will  change.   As far as overall game concept this game follows along with the old Road Rash feel and that is perfect for me.  The game is FUN.  Is it perfect
date: nope.  Was I expecting it to be at this point
recommended: nope.   Do I think it has the chance to become a great game
hoursPlayed: yes.  At this point in development do I feel like it is worth risking the full asking price of $20?  Yes if you played Road Rash or looking for a fun game that doesn't take itself too serious then I do.   The game doesn't have a lot of "meat" in it yet but even so what is on the bones so far is worth the money.  I have spent a lot more for a lot less fun."
voteText: July 5, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking to satisfy a Road Rash craving, this will do the trick. If you don't know what Road Rash is, it's kind of like a racing game with beat em up elements. This game offers some rouge-like elements, the levels are a little random, and when you die, it's over, but you earn perks for your next run. The perks are very minor, Road Redemption is still a racing beat em up, not a grindy rpg.

Unlike many other games in early access, I have seen this game continue to grow and update. The game lacks a few things, some new modes might be nice. More diverse AI would add a lot, they seem to all act pretty much the same way. While some randomization is great, as it adds replay value, there is just too much. Knocking a biker off feels like killing a random monster in a mmo, another will just spawn and take its place. There are no grudges, or personalities, and often riders who have nothing to do with your current race will try to attack you for no reason.

Most importantly, despite its few flaws, it's a fun game. It runs well, the screen shots and videos accurately depict the graphics. I have not had the game crash, slow down, or had any noticeable bugs. I feel the game is worth it at full price, and I expect it to continue to get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only had the game for a little while, but it's pretty fun. I'm not really familiar with the Road Rash series, but upon learning about it's general concept, and seeing this game, I decided to try it out. It's a pretty fun, fast paced game, and it's pretty challenging too. For the most part, I have no complaints.

However, I do have 2, and they are pretty much the only sources of dislike for this game. The first is the physics and hit-detection. For example, when careening down the highway, say you hit a car head-on. Most times, as expected, you'll go flying off your bike. However, sometimes, you'll instead be pushed by the car while still on your bike, and you won't be able to move until it knocks you off your bike. This same scenario can happen if a car or truck hits you from behind, or if you hit a random pipe or box in the road or on the side. You'll be stuck, and you can't move, unless you manage to shimmy out of the scenario. In a fast-paced game like this one, no matter how good you drive, one mistake can mean the difference between success and failure.

The other has to do with damage (and enemy hit detection), which I find wildly inconsistent. For example, I can be going at it with a rival biker, and our weapons clash against each other. For some reason, I'll still take damage, even though a) the enemy doesn't, and b) the enemy weapon hit my weapon, not my body. Also, there have been plenty of times where I can be hit with a pipe and even with max health, instantly be killed, while I can be hit by c4 and only lose half of my life. It seems like no matter how much life you have, with the inconsistent damage, you can truly feel safe on the road.

Regardless, even with those bugs, the game is still worth it. It's a very challenging game, but if you can overcome, you'll be handsomely rewarded. In it's current state, 7/10 for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The moment I saw this game on Steam. I knew I wanted it. Just watching the trailer for it brought back all my old memories of playing Road Rash back in the day. The game doesn't disappoint. While it doesn't share all the same qualities, it's still enough to satisfy my nostalgia.

It's crazy fun when you ignore the obvious learning curve. You need to definitely level up a bit to even stand a chance against the later levels in the campaign or just pure mastering of all you have at your disposal. There's also a Campaign+ Mode which gets even crazier with the difficulty and chaotic mayhem. I haven't had a chance to try the split screen yet, but from what I've seen from videos, It looks like a blast...Then there's also the elephant in the room. Yeah, I'm hoping Multiplayer Online will be added soon. Until then, at least we have offline co-op.

Overall, from what I've experienced from the game. It's great. I hope it gets even better with new modes and all the kinks worked out in the future when it's finished. Keep it up, Devs!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I keep telling myself I won't invest in any more Early Access titles, yet here I am. I remember trading my SNES for my friend's Genesis a lot of weekends in Jr. High, and the Road Rash series was one of the biggest reasons. This game takes the timeless concept of armed crazies on motorcycles racing on public roads for fame and fortune to another level.

Probably the biggest upgrade, online multiplayer, isn't implemented yet, but what is here now is already as fun as the original games. What's already been added to the original schematic is local multiplayer, rooftop levels, hallucinatory" levels with cars falling from the sky and crashing into each other at every turn
date: awesome avatars with flaming jack-o-lantern heads
recommended: and a permanent experience based upgrade path on top of the cash upgrades that dissapear after each game ends.  I definitely don't regret this purchase."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRoad Redemption is memorable to me because it was the first game that was given to me by a developer to review, presumably because they had mistaken me for somebody important. I decided to go back and play it again recently because I remembered it being pretty fun, and then saw that I forgot to ever actually write anything about it, which is probably why the only other developer who ever gave me a game to review was the one who made that Hat Man game that I gave a bad review for. But on to Road Redemption. Road Redemption is a fun little game with equal emphasis on racing and combat, in which you try to survive your way through a trail of races and eliminations. You gain both cash and XP as you progress, but if you die then it's game over, and you restart from the beginning with only your XP upgrades carried over. The combat is pretty fun and fleshed out; you can grab other racers and steer them into oncoming traffic, kick them off bridges, shoot them, or just get in with a battle axe or a lead pipe and bash and counter your way to victory. Road Redemption is a game where 1st place" can either mean "stay ahead of the other racers" or "be the only racer left"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Once upon a time in the nineties, relaxation after a hard day at school was emitting a sigh of relief, booting the PlayStation to hear the dulcet tones of Road Rash 3D (and by dulcet tones, I mean real metal songs like 'Rusty Cage'. That might not seem much now, but before the GTA series this was something of a rariety in a game).

Apparently, according to wikipedia Road Rash 3D wasn't well received at the time. Well it was by me having by that point probably wasted months in the Road Rash games on the megadrive. As such, this modern day rip off homage has an awful lot to live up to.

Things are still rough and ready, but the core of the game is there.

On the bad hand; the split screen multiplayer is workable but has bugs, the network play is still completely missing and the bikes feel like they are cruising far too smoothly and quickly over the road surface - it's not just the final rainbow road" style track that makes you think you could be playing a karting game.

This should be unforgiveable
date: but...it's somehow not.\n\nIt's a testament to the Road Rash legacy for those who grew up with it that Road Redemption still makes me grin every time I fire it up after an update
recommended: whether it's surviving a pile up
hoursPlayed: loosing a lorry load of logs off a passing trailer on a trecherous bend with a well placed sword swipe or kicking an opposing rider off a bridge.\n\nIt also has something I don't remember in Road Rash
voteText: guns!\n\nSimply put
helpfulPercent: this game has massive potential. In my mind's eye I imagine netplay with clans of bikers riding a race or grudge match against one another. I can almost hear the grenade launcher calling out for it. I can hear the swearing and the laughter over the voice comm.\n\nFor now
votesHelpful: Road Redempton is worth supporting as no one else is doing a similar game. Buy it (or con someone else into doing so :D) give it a play through
votesTotal: then get a few ciders in and try the split screen with some buddies
votesFunny: preferably on the hallucinogenic chemical zone level
commentsCount: where cars fall from the sky. There are far worse ways to waste your day."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you loved the 90's game Road Rash which came out on the Sega Megadrive then you will find this game quite enjoyable. It is no where near the acheivement that Road Rash was but with this being early access I am hoping it can get closer to it. Currently it is not worth the price tag. There is no where near enough content to keep you going longer than a few hours. The races are short which can be irritating if you fall off near the as you will not have enough time to catch up, they are quite often extremely hectic and it is primarily luck that ensures you get through it. There can be bombs exploding, cars flying everywhere, cars swerving all over the road and occasionally cars that fall from the sky in the aptly titled halucineagenic zone.  There are two lots of upgrades, temporary ones which last for as long as you are alive and are bought with cash won from races and ones you buy once dead with the XP you have earned whilst alive. This is quite fun but again not a patch on Road Rash. I would like to see shops in which to purchase new bikes and parts to upgrade the one you have and new outfits to buy and things like armour. The races need to be longer as you are just getting into them when they come to an end, an end which allows you to carry on riding until the gane loads. I would like to see something of a story too, not anything dramatic like Grandma needs a new hip but doesn't have insurance so I race to pay for it kinda crap but just yes we race it's what we do. In Road Rash there was characters I didn't want to fight with as they always said nice things to me and there were jerks you didn't mind repeatedly bashing. Something like that is always fun. And dear god please lose the Mariocart level, currently the last level, riding on a rainbow in space? Come on, you lost me there.

In summary this is a fun game and a good way to waste some spare minutes but so far the content is lacking and the races are too short. But otherwise an enjoyable experience, unfotunately not worth the current price tag.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Okay so this game is kind of re-birth of Road Rash series which is made on unity, the game itself plays good and even betr than classic, but for now it lacks moar content (mostly cuz its one-run kind of game, so its okay).
The devs are trying to make the game as good as possible, and i've deleted my prev. negative review claiming that achivs are broken and devs ignore this... now i know they don't so this game will be 100%able soon, for now - just ~56%.
Graphics: Everything looks good, stuff explodes, and graphics don't eat too much resources. (10/10)
Gameplay: It's fun even if you play it few more times, you can use either firearms or cold weapons, both are useful. You have a choice of bikes and stuff. (10/10)
Setting: Gangs, bikes and stuff in different parts of USA, gud nuff. (9/10)
Controls: everything is fine as well, but deflection doesn't work for now. (7/10)
Story: <Do you need any here?>
Replayability: Kinda high cuz its the main thing about this game, you get skills that carry over to next playthroughs so it can be easier. I immediately played this game again and then Campaign +, was kinda disapointed not getting an achievement tho :c (to be fixed) (10/10)

Overall rating: 9.2/10 (S)
The game is worth buying, but beware of that its not so long one, you might want to go for all achivs (once they are fixed), otherwise you will overpay cuz of low time spent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mostly fun, with controller in hand ready to go this game plays well out of the box. We all know what game this reminds us older players of. Here we are in a different time to do it all again, better and brutal online. Im really looking forward to the coming year of updates to gauge the level invested by this Louisiana company.

Features I find lacking or just bugs.

- Poor leaning on the bike
- No cat walks or stoppies
- Double health skill carries to ng+ but starting level 3 & $1500 does not
- Starting a race is always set up at paces from other bikes and based on distance, its possible to not start a race until you want there is no time limit just a bar telling you when you finish
- Maybe add street races where you all have a starting line and the option to have a delay to use weapons
- Buying from the store the double dmg for the next race is bs garbage, its a gamble. make it a xp skill
- There is no proper way to quit after you finish a race and spend exp if youre not dead.
- No proper brake, just forward and reverse. never puts leg down.
- The check points between levels to buy stuff show have more random one type of item(e.g cb radio, +mass/kg but can hear chatter maybe learn a thing, chains as weapons, screwdrivers, mail boxes, a whip, road beers, ♥♥♥♥ jugs, etc)
- More chatter between all motorists, gestures too.
- Mission to get 4of 4 stars you have to drive slow before reaching the end. its a problem of too short of a distance.
- Cash into exp store item should display the ratio of $:exp.
- Disarming a rider does nothing but killing a guy nets you a weapon...kick a guy off a roof top much.
- Hands not attached to the handle bars
- The magnum hand gun is large compare to our players hand, compare it to the harpoon gun in size.
- Why is it with a handgun equipped that three different buttons are used to fire a gun?
- More race modes: Defeating mob bosses on bikes with gang in tow, Tsunami run where you stay ahead of the death hunting you down, Hallucinegenic Zone you have an ability to slow time(e.g Max Payne 3 online) allowing the rider to  duck and weave.
- Intersections, over passes, on ramps off ramps. get those alt routes
- Not enough variations, the style going is very spaced out 0_0
- Steamworks or GTFO


Overall 7, because there is only 7 levels and it plays very well. Its not even half way across to what appears the end. At this time the game is .827 in Early Access. I like the randomness and hope to see a roguelike story making choices. Im sure to spend many hours playing once multiplayer rolls up


july 4 2015 - Alot has changed ng+ is tough and need to set yourself up to be able to compete so you dont die. basically if you barely beat a level and used all your boost you wont beat the next lvl. the new build look is nice, but it really shows how detailed it looks like a arcade cabinet game. There is still no multiplayer or bikes. Alot of fleshed out snags, power up attacks and more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road Redemption is a spiritual successor of the Road Rash Series. I have played only one Road Rash game before, which was on my Playstation. When I played Road Redemption for the first time, I really got that feeling that this is really a worthy follow up after the series, with modern graphics, physics, etc.

In this early access version, you're gonna be playing the campaign mode which lasts 12 levels, not unlike a rogue like setup. You go from level to level with various objectives, got some temporary upgrades in between which will be gone when you die, and then get to buy some permanent upgrades like health, damage, etc. With my poor skills, it took me 4 hours to finally finish this early access portion.

As for what you do in the game itself, there are race-type levels, take down, weird platforming level with a just-cause-y grappling hook, and a few other variations (like racing with cars raining from the sky). I have to say they really nail that feel when you hit enemies in the face. It's just so damn satisfying ! Kicking your enemy to make him crash a truck is even more fun, although a bit more difficult. There are also a few types of guns which makes your job of killing people very, very easy compared to hitting people directly in which you can take some damage. Maybe it'll be better if they nerf it a little. Nothing game breaking though.

My two cents is that even though this is a very early access, I get the feeling that the final product is going to be epic. The developers are great and they patch the game almost everyday, sometimes twice a day, and are also active in the forum. I fully recommend this game for those of you who likes hitting people in the face (who doesn't ?).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's like Dark Souls on motorcycles.


Actually, being a huge fan of Road Rash back in the day, this game scratches that bike combat itch really nicely. It's still not nearly perfect but it's still amazing in it's current state. That bone crunching sound and puff cloud of blood followed by your enemy getting flung off their bike is what you live for in this game and it's oh so satisfying.

The splitscreen multiplayer is also super hecticly fun and hilarious.

Definitely a huge recommendation from me.

EDIT: The game has had some updates here and there really adding nothing to the game besides fixing some minor bugs that I never ran into. I haven't seen an update in over a month. And calm the ♥♥♥♥ down people, the Dark Souls thing was an obvious joke.

Cons
-The UI still looks terrible and the handling can still be weird at times.

-AI has been updated to be more agressive, but all that has done is make the AI gang up on you or fly past you and hit you perfectly with a weapon without even stopping. It's honestly made the AI a lot more annoying and not more difficult and they can" stick to you like glue no matter if you're going over a jump or slapping that nitro
recommended: they will literally lose all air momentum and stick to you in the air
hoursPlayed: hit you and then take off in mid air. They can be really ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t at times.\n\nThe game isn't bad
voteText: I still have a lot of fun with it
helpfulPercent: but the devs really need to step up their game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you played and enjoyed Road Rash on the N64, you're gonna love this one.

Shoot/grab/ram/whack enemies and avoid traffic. Pretty darn fun. The ragdoll physics makes for some hilarious accidents. There's still a lot I need to learn about the game regarding equipment purchases and what not but I'm enjoying the game. The maps are huge. One game I accidently trailed off the road and ended up just riding the mountains. I wasn't glitched out of the map or anything, I was just ridin all around. Kinda like an open world, just with me being so far away there weren't any other enemies/cars, etc.

And while I've had fun with the gameplay, the music is great as well. Really feels like you're playing a classic". The sounds and music give it a nice arcade feel.

If you're bored with the games you have and just want to have goofy fun

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So First off I really love roadrash, the idea of a more battle focused roadrash is awesome, but I feel the game developer is taking this game in the wrong direction. For example, 3 levels in your bike gets unlimited jet booster pack that propels your bike way high in the air, most of the maps take place on rooftops and are poorly designed and involve jump after jump and its just awful. maps where the entire road is laced with c4 bombs that are all timed to go off quite randomly or maps where cars are always falling from the sky, its neat and all but its in there way too much,out of the maps selection theres only about 2 that are any fun and you dont get to select the maps theyre all generated by the computer. The ones that are fun are super fun, I do love this game alot but honestly i find myself quitting campaigns over and over due to having to race on rooftops all the damn time. I'd like to see it stick to the road rash roots more, and less goofy crap, this game has the feel at time of a modern day road warrior at times and has potential to be amazingly fun.I know this game is early access and there will be alot of improvements i just hope they pour their resources into making more decent maps and less wacky over the top game killer but they seem dedicated to their stupid bike jet pack

I'd like this game alot better without the bike jet packs, without the rooftop platform jump levels, without the explosive road levels, without the cars falling from the sky levels, without the cartoonish rainbow level.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As is this is a wonderfully fun game. Very much like road rash. I gave put about 6 hours into it and have finished the standard playthrough with the option to due new game+. I have completed my skill tree and I believe I've seen every weapon there is, so far.

Pros:
Great Road Rash like game with replayability.
Good artwork. (not that you can tell because of speed and stuff going on)
Diverse weapon selection
Decent rider selection with different abilities

In-betweens:
A lot going on in a race. Might have to block while turning while dodging that car, oh watch out for that semi behind you that slams into you.
Rooftop levels....

Cons:
The physics sometimes don't do what you would expect. Like a head-on with a car might get you stuck against the hood rolling backwards instead of throwing you to the pavement.
Currently the cars' drivers have a standin model that is just a crash test dummy
The grappling gun sometimes would attach to something behind or to the side rather than the target I'm aiming at.

Overall:
Great game, fun and fast. You will probably end up stopping in the middle because of something stupid that happens, but you will come back.
There is multiplayer but I haven't had a chance to play it yet.
$20 might be a little high for the 6 or so hours you will put in, I'd recommend getting it during a sale.

11/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So this is early access and in alpha.

It's pretty much Road Rash taken to 11.  You get guns, a samurai sword, c4, all kinds of weapons, a nitro boost, a jetpack maneuver, a really responsive drift, oceans of traffic, and various objectives.

It is also very much like a rogue-like.  You earn experience and cash by beating up other racers and completing objectives.  You start with one life and you buy yourself upgrades and/or lives with cash to continue beating random, escalating scenarios. You spend experience on permanent upgrades after you run out of lives and those upgrades will carry over to a fresh cycle (pun not intended).

Graphics are very good, but lacking an artistic direction to really set it over the top to make it something unique and special.  The music covers many different genres, and it is basically all very good and upbeat.

Also, there is ragdoll.

I don't recommend buying at the price they're offering.  I would recommend it at five bucks.  It's one of the better arcade experiences I've played and it's only in alpha.

Road Rash? No. Close but it's not Road Rash, this game have it's own distinct flavor.
Does it good overall? Not in the current state. It's labeled Early Access for a reason.
Does it worth it's money? Now this is a big YES. This is a promising title full of enthusiasm. Unpolished, buggy, laggy and with ugly graphics in it's current state but gameplay wise it is good already and this is what matters.

You can wait to buy it later or just buy it now to check for yourself. Both decisions have a valid points IMHO. But game like Road Redemption deserve attention and it's not something that you should miss.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I think the core foundation of this game is pretty solid, but it's still in early access. I'm not that big a fan of the music, or the menus, but the core gameplay is really fun. It's a little rough around the edges but the developers seem to be continuing to engage with the community on the Steam forums and there is an official launch planned for later this year so hopefully they can iron out some of the problems. The updates they have planned look promising and I'm excited to try out the new features for myself.

(It does kind of bug me that the default player character is set to Biker Santa Claus. I kinda wish there were more customization options for your biker..  But honestly, my biggest complaints are the kind of sloppy looking UI and menus that look very plain and not really stylized. It needs more polish!)

The driving and combat feels solid, and even the guns and shooting feel simple to use. The upgrade system, with a shop between levels, is a neat addition to a game like this, but again, the menu/UI for this stuff needs work. Same goes for the permanent upgrades that persist between playthroughs.

If the final product comes out and it's more or less the same, I don't think I would recommend it, but as it is, with updates on the way and a developer actually communicating with the fans, I'm happy to support them and I eagerly anticipate the future builds.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AddictiveRoad Redemption (RR) is, in a word: addictive.

Fast paced, challenging, and surprisingly well rounded- (despite being early access) RR is a welcome addition to the action-racing genre.

In RR you play as a member of a motorcycle gang, armed to the teeth with various weapons ranging from a Viking axe, to a grenade launcher.

Timing your strikes is key, as well as micromanaging, as you battle both the traffic, and members of opposing gangs in game modes that are both bizarre, and extremely fun to master.

Multiplayer has been promised, and is in the works- and will only serve as a boon to the title's popularity.

If you are a fan of racing, and fast paced combat: Road Redemption is a gaming experience not to be missed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most of Early Access is garbage. Either the designs are poor, the funding is clearly lacking and it will never be completed, or they're simply not fun to pay. There's usually a reason a developer can't find a publisher.

Not so with Road Redemption. I'm stunned this hasn't been picked up by a publisher already.

The visuals are solid, the gameplay is hilarious and bombastic, the weapons and tracks are diverse, interesting and feel excellent to use. Most of all, this is a ♥♥♥♥ing VIDEO GAME. It's such a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ video game you don't even know - it's just a freaking blast to play, a huge amount of fun. The upcoming multiplayer component is extremely promising as well.

The only thing lacking might be the music, which is somewhat generic, as well as some variability in the missions. However, the devs seem to have their heads screwed on right and this promises to be a ♥♥♥♥ing awesome game.

Give them your money, now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is rough around the edges. If you're careful about it you can even fly through entire races using your grappling hook like some sort of Hell's Angel/Spiderman hybrid. Its riddled with bugs and the mechanics behind races means its nearly impossible to catch up to rival racers in several modes.
Despite the unpolished bits the combat has an incredibly satisfying sense of crunch. Since everyone is flying along at hundreds of miles per hour any hit that connects sends enemies flying like you just hit a home run. Hopefully as development goes on we'll see the rest of gameplay get tightened up a bit, right now it probably isn't worth a buy, but there is definitely enough here to have a real gem of a game in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is in early access, so you already know what that means: it's not complete and it's a little rough in some spots. That said, I unexpectedly played this game for about 4 hours straight because I was having a lot of fun. Here's a section of gameplay with cars raining from the sky:

http://youtu.be/JwgR8L9wAOo
Some of you may be too young to have ever played Road Rash, but this game is on track to being better than one of the classics from my childhood. Players get a bike and have various objectives while racing around deserts, icy mountains and even city skylines. Much like Road Rash, the player is armed and able to kick and attack other bikers with weapons. Unlike Road Rash, however, Road Redemption has a huge arsenal of melee weapons and guns to lay waste to others on the road. Pasting C4 on bikers and blasting a cop car with a gernade launcher is exteremly fun.

So far, only some single player content is in, but multiplayer is on the way. Road Redemption has a few different mission types that vary from get the attention of the police" to "kill all these guys without weapons" and they mix up the gameplay quite a bit. Presently: when a mission is completed
date: you're on to the next level. Completing these challenges and killing enemy bikers and cars gives you cash for buying upgrades for the next level. When you die
hoursPlayed: and you lose all your cash and upgrades. However
voteText: there's also a skill system
helpfulPercent: where you use experience points earned from killing bikers and cops to buy upgrades for things like health
votesHelpful: better starting weapons and more nitro boosts. It's a little rough at the moment (the tree itself could use some visual tweaks)
votesTotal: but the idea is awesome for a game of this style.\n\nSo far
votesFunny: the only negatives I can even think of are some bugs and preformance issues. The game chugs a bit (probably due to physics stuff since changing quality and antialiasing doesn't change it much)
commentsCount: but it's still surprisingly playable during this. There's a few infinite loading bugs that I can't seem to reproduce
column16: and once I got stuck in the skyline when I fell inbetween some buildings
column17: but otherwise nothing that some polish won't fix."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of v0.816:
Road Redemption is a kickstarted spiritual successor for 90-s Road Rash series.
And, well, it's pretty damn good at re-making the gameplay and overall feel of the Road Rash series.
Bikes, tons of weapons, fighting on the road, kicking opponents into the abyss - all of this is there.
But Road Redemption is a very silly game (in a good way). Not even once it considers itself serious.
Expect tornados throwing cars all around the level, bomb that appear out of nowhere to blow you and your opponents up as well as crazy rides on the rooftops (with your regular traffic around as well, yep).
Most of the things in game are randomly generated. While this means you can literally play it endlessly and get a new experience every time, this also brings in some issues.
For example, sometimes roads are generated in a very strange way so that you cannot really see what's coming next.
The fog from explosions seems to be just a texture (or maybe it's just the particles are not transparent at all?) and you cannot really see what's behind it.
Some of those random things makes you feel cheated when you lose because of them.
They are definitely fixable, though. And every patch makes them a bit better.
In general it's a very pleasantly and crazy experience for those of you who want to scratch that Road Rash itch, as well as just for people looking to have some motorcycle combat fun.

More detailed look in the video:
http://youtu.be/TaY36btUeA8

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Players Beware, This isn't a typical road rash clone. The level progression can be a little like Road Rash Jailbreak if any one still remembers that.
You get so far into the game, and once you get a game over, You have to start all the way back to square one.
This game is a little more lenient because you can gain XP to level up your skill tree. One Notch on the tree is to start from level 3 instead of level 1.
A solid Check point system would be way better than having to buy them by failing Countless amounts of times.
The AI can be really aggressive in some areas and really hard to complete the objective. Once you run out of super Melees, It's almost impossible to Knock the AI's Off their bikes In the Eliminate X amount of Opponents.
In Road rash and other games, if you countered at the right time you got to take their weapons from them and stun them for a second making the progression doable. In Road Redemption you just dodge, and hope a gang of 10 other Bikers and Cops Don't Knock you out instantly sending you all the way back to either level one or the last purchased check point.

The item system, though Unique makes the game interesting. There is a choice of Guns or melee weapons, like shovels, axes, bats ect.
The bad thing is aiming while steering the bike. The environments can be so chaotic it makes the guns hard to use. So i don't. The weapons have health, so when they are depleted, you can't fight back or counter once you exhaust your last weapon.
The weapons also Auto cycle when you knock out another biker. So if you like a particular weapon be prepared to get the next thing that comes your way.

I like the health system concept this game has going for it and the screen affects when you have low health. You can Gain a little bit of health by knocking out other AI's. The bad, is in the Game mode where you have to take out X number of opponents. They tend to Clump together and gang up on you. Even The AI's that don't have cursors over their heads, and some of the other Cars.

The controls need more polishing, Needs a better turning radius. There is no way to make sharp turns, you have slowing down. There are some areas where you have to slow way down, or you will crash into a mountain or drive over it and fly out into the rest of the unpopulated map.

This game reminds me very much of Road rash. I loved that game. This Game has made a lot of good updates since it had released.
Being able to do wheelys over objects and cars would be nice instead of face planting into them. Also whats up with car's and other vehicles being competition? I thought this was a bike only game.  It's fun, but a little confusing, hard and Chaotic at times. Still hadnt beaten it, but i do have a logn way to go with the way the game is.
Keep up the good work developers, I hope my review helped.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI'm not going to recommend this game YET. The bones are good - solid controls, satisfying basic mechanics, and a nice feel to the whole thing. I just can't tell, from the game's present state, whether or not there's a bigger idea for a game here. As it stands now, you're really repeating the same three or four events over and over, and I sense they're trying to compensate for the skimpy content by making it harder to play than it should be. (Try the rooftop level once, and you'll see what I mean.) Fingers crossed that this early access title lives up to its potential!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey, you!  Buy this game!  It's every bit as fun as it looks.  The bikes are satisfying to ride.  The physics are more arcadey than realistic, meaning they're fun and forgiving.  Even with a mouse & keyboard it controls fine.  The weapons are hilarious, from knocking a rider's block off with a long shovel to slapping a C4 time bomb on his back.  When that fails, you can grab a rider and steer him into traffic, or just kick him right off a bridge.

There are different mission types, and while there is permadeath, your upgraded skills carry over into subsequent playthroughs.  Also, the soundtrack is fantastic.  The developer has been very active, releasing updates as often as every day since I picked this up during the last summer sale.

The downsides I've noticed include the interface, which is kind of ugly and poorly structured.  The rooftop levels aren't as solid as the open road levels, but they're getting there.  If multiplayer is of paramount importance, you'd better wait.  For everyone else, this game is already plenty of fun in its current state.  To put it differently, I don't see buying this now as a gamble, unlike other Early Access games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I hope this review gets the devlopers attention while it is early access and has time to be fixed. I seriously want to love this game, but there are a lot of design flaws beyond bug fixes that simply do not make the game enjoyable.

A great example of this is the skill tree, which should be scrapped entirely for a new unlock system that changes your starting weapons and unlocks new motorcycles. Increasing your health, xp gains, and cast earned isn't healthy game play fun - its grindy and does not feel rewarding to the player.
Instead, picture that you only start the game off with a single character and bike, no weapons, and have to earn your way up the ranks. As you spend your xp after each match you unlock new characters (that start with a single weapon) or bikes with real differences. You shouldnt start each game with 3 weapons immediately, already on stage 3, and nearly irrelevant bike choices just because you played through a few times. I know it's early access - but this is the kind of thing that is getting old quickly.

The game also completely lacks personality from the other racers, and to make it worse it is littered with a bunch of randomly spawned NPC's to up the action. Instead keep my 10 or so competitors and make them challenging, make them try to grab me and block my shots, or boost when I try to shoot at them. Give them names and pictures, dialouge, they need personality.

Lastly, since right now your current objectives are all random - it makes for some frustrating game play. I don't mind the tornado, explosions in the middle of the road constantly levels, or roof top timed challenge modes existing.... if there was a choice to it. If i could choose to want to play that or not it would really help. I want a core gameply driven experience when I hit campaign, and I want a challenge type scenario placed elsewhere. My campaign should be an experience of improvement and difficulty to be the best racer out there, not dodging randomly generated falling cars.

The game is still fun, but I am not recommending it until I see some real direction put into the game instead of a bunch of randomly placed together content and skill trees.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your looking through the reviews and seeing all the Thumbs Up, please take the time to look at the number of hours put into the game, then look at when the review was put in. This should be enough to tell you that you will not play much of the game.

I didn't like it. Maybe I am just a little to young (20) to have played the games that were like this back in the day so I don't get the whole nastalgia feeling or anything, but if you want a throw back or enjoy the simple games where you just try to get further or try to get a higher score than last time... ok.

Starting the game out, you get on your bike, you press forward and depending on situations... you never stop pressing W. Time your whacks right and you get a hit on a guy who then get some strange spead boost if he isn't dead in the first hit. Get a gun and shot your enemies... only takes one shot usually but the maps are just full of bends, there really arent any straight aways or anything, so you miss most of your shots.

Graphics... not great. The models for the game were not made that well. They represent the object being displayed just fine but there should have been a lot more vertices for a game that is so simple. Map design... lots of cars on the road, and a few things on the side. That is all, nothing more than that, your done. Just stay on the road or suffer a large penalty to move speed off it.

Respawns... I once ran into a car on accident and I respawned, only to be pancaked instantly (theres about 2/3 of my heal gone), respawned once more and got ran into from behind this time by a semi. Guess what? Game over, start over again with the same boring winding roads with the same weapons and maybe one more upgrade but probably not.

So I guess since I come from a primarily FPS and MMO background, this kind of game was just never suited for me anyway. If your into games that are similar to this, then I'm sure you will enjoy it. But I don't like the boring grinds of the same thing over and over again. I enjoy challenges, but I like challenges that are different each time, this is just the same set of missions over and over until you get past the one you died at.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know its not the finished product, so I can only review what I see.  As a huge fan of Road Rash I dont really like what I see here.  Why not just update the Road Rash already award winning game design? As others have pointed out I think the team has missed some crucial parts to what made Road Rash ..well Road Rash..  In this game here is no rivalries, the game play is similar but not as good as in the past. Hell I even miss the crashing and running back to the bike, it added a touch of realism, this new version is all too arcadey.

Plus the music is aweful, I mean terrible with a capital T.  The bike and game sound effects need to be much more distinct, deeper, richer.  I should be hearing the bike deep in the bass of my speakers, instead ..nothing much at all.


Plus the physics of the bike dont feel right either. The bike doesnt feel as if it has any weight to it.

Sorry, I was hoping for more

reviewText:
Early Access Review

5/10

I wanted to like this game...err did I?...in fact I may have been looking for an entirely different game altogether.

Let me explain. I'm an older gamer (40) that remembers the original Road Rash games on the Sega Genesis. Back in the day, I loved these original bike beaters, and when I saw this - a blatant copy (or maybe homage?) of the original series, I just had to have it. Note to self : DON'T BUY GAMES WHEN YOU ARE DRINKING!

The graphics are just okay in this game, but the gameplay itself is very limited and doesn't have that much replay value. I think I could pop in the old games on the sega (*If i had one)  and have more fun. I didn't ask for my money back, as firstly, I do like to support indie developers and secondly, I didn't want to admit I had made a drunken blunder and purchased this crappy game... (Sorry Mr. Developer- but for my $12, I DO get to call it crappy).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For better or worse, not what I wanted from the spiritual successor of Road Rash game. I'll admit I'm far too biased to say whether this is over-all a good game or not on its own merits, but I feel it has drifted too far from the Road Rash roots it came from for me to be able to enjoy it. If you happen to be considering this game because of those roots, I definitely recommend going on youtube and watching someone else play it rather than just relying on the trailer.

The game feels a lot like Burnout Paradise to me, not necessarily in gameplay but in style. A lot of people do seem to like that style, but I prefer a bit more grit and subtlty.

As I sad earlier. Not a bad game, just not for me. And my concern is that people wanting another Road Rash may be disappointed by the direction the changes have taken this game. Caveat Emptor, do your research and make sure this is what you're looking for before you buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is an amazing revival of the classics that i enjoyed on PS1. I cant give too much info on it at this point since the game lags too much for me to try everything out. Local Multiplayer, online multiplayer aint out yet. Character loadout and perk system is interesting. I love the fact i can change my weapons, to even guns xD. A lot of carnage, and a lot of crashing (for everyone) for other people the game may work smoothly right now....but not everyone. Its a good game to support at this time tho.

Edit #1: After 2-3 updates, the performance of the overall game has only improved slightly to the point where it starts off fine but then gets worse and worse. I have a high end gaming laptop that normally can handle games smoothly with no problems when others say they cant play properly, but not for this game. I dont know about anyone else though. Anyways.....the latest updates did come out with some new interesting content that does add on to the overall game, like new characters, weapons etc. They did state that there was some huge performance fixes but as i said.....i dont see them. because of the still current lag-fest i have not been able to get more then a total of 1 hour playing. But im sure more updates will come soon and i will try again for my second Edit of this review.

Edit #2: We got another decent update with a few smaller ones before hand, and even tho they add to the campaign, i still can't play on any graphics settings higher then Fastest". And even on Fastest it lags a lot. This is my main concern with this game over any new content."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road Redemption is refreshed old Road Rash on Mega Drive and Play Station. It has all what we loved in these games: tons of adrenaline and madness, hi-speed fights and destruction (hoping of some wild life in the future of RR).
But there is some new stuff:
- firearms (AK47 and M79 Blooper are taste so good!),
- races across rooftops (use jump jets and grapple helicopters with a harpoon),
- and finally - ride a rainbow!

So, if someone hasn't decided yet - remove all doubts and buy!

PS And try to imagine yourself ride the bike while shooting with a lever action shotgun (just like in Terminator 2 movie) in truck carrying logs (Final Destination 2) to release them right on your opponents... That's awesome!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhen I first fired up this game I didn't know what to think, it certainly isn't the prettiest game out there and it could use a bit of polish, but give it 10 minutes and you'll be hooked. If any of you have played Road Rash for the N64, Road Redemption is like that but on bath salts and with guns. A few issues I have with the game are when there's a lot of ♥♥♥♥ onscreen like when a logging truck spills logs all over the road or if there's a car storm" the FPS drops to the single digits. The city rooftop tracks are also pretty shafty especially when you're forced to use the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ grappling hook to swing from crane to helicopter. Bugs aside this game looks really promising and hopefully once coop is added and the campaign mode is fleshed out it will get better."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SPIDERBIKE! SPIDERBIKE!
More like SPIDER RASH... I backed this thing up because I'm hopelessly addicted to the 1995 Roadrash for PC (remember the friggin awesome Soundtracks on that one?) the rail rider mechanic (having the screen pull your bike around wherever the road bends and you got to pull in that direction to keep in lane or avoid collisions). Expect me to endlessly compare this UNITY engine stinker to the good ol' boy classic. My name is Milwaukee Jon !

Now I know this is Early Access and I am writing TWO notes here to edit this review whenever I see significant changes.

First off: Unity? FFFFFUUUUUUUUU...
Runs like @$$. I'm serious. I have seen better Tetris 3D clones with more destruction and particle effects that run like a waterfall (constant). I have just recently grabbed Receiver (thx Bundle store) for free and I am willing to accept its low poly plastic look that runs as $H!T as anything else with the touch of the Unitron.
I guess the engine was picked for a reason (looking at you Linux and MacOS) but ffs is it underperforming.

Could be because I do not own a 1337 PC GAMING MASTER RACE accredited machine. I don't give two about that becaue I played games in the past decade that a) run like hell and b) look like paradise at the same time while you get your lil avatar ♥♥♥ raped by the superb AI that handles most of your surroundings. All the while my machine was switched to energy saving settings.

Anyway:
Soundtrack is a bit here and there. I really like some of those electro tunes (shiz beatz and all the shebang) but on the other side the metal tunes cannot possibly compare to the grunge awesome that was included in the classic. However if you compare the stage themes (there were 5 in the classic) and this one that puts random themes everytime you reload a stage I guess it is somewhat better because you know it is an actual track and not a MIDI tune with fake instruments from the system repository.

Controls: As I expected it is an upgrade in dimensions. You have thrusters to do quick jumps and doubletap to activate a constant booster instead of boost capsules that needed to be timed well in the classic to have an effect. You can turn around, drive here and there, only limited by the camera pitch towards the center but OH WAIT, mouse now controls the camera and the combat. The one hit takedowns work nicely and blocking seems to be OK. There is even a hook gun that when mastered can become your best tool while chasing rivals or evading obstacles. Spiderman approved!

Video and Settings: Change resolution, windowed or FS, AA, VS. all that $H!T takes a nose dive because on weak rigs you can pretty much forget about it. Doesn't matter what you pick. Fastest is still beyond min. playability. The more is happening on screen the worse stuttering gets. I usually just skipped the city rooftop stages whenever I lost too much HP cause they are pointless when the best I get are 12 FPS...

Gameplay:
One hit takedowns (crticals) are often, booster gets me up to max speed when I need it but doesn't help chasing well placed opponents although the game cuts you some slack like the classic did. The opponents are often gathered near frontrunner so if you manage to drive fast and not fly off your bike or get  stuck  SUPER GLUED  to the rear of a car (wtf man?) then you have a good chance to overtake all them suckas at once (thx to the popo beating up everyone and occasional car storms (yes you heard right, CARS dropping out of the sky onto the track like ultra heavy rain drops of the apocalypse!!!). I felt like a D@m// wizard while a few hundred meters in front of me cars spawned out of nowhere and crushed the opposition and pesky pigs.

As mentioned in the beginning. Hook gun comes complete with bungee rope and all that gud stuff. While midair you can turn directions like Mario and not give a flying pair of ducks about inertia or silly physics. YOU ARE THE PHYSICS! Oh what is that, a huge boulder? NOPE! it's a perfectly fine ramp. Just dash into it and get catapulted back on track while blasting fools from above with your hitscan AK, UMP, Shotie and grenade launcher. Hell yeah.

I guess at this point I gotta pull the emergency brakes: See, the classic was inspired by the console versions. The combat felt up close and personal because you AND your rivals had a health bar that regenerated once downed. It was fists vs. fists, chains, bats. The opponents had names displayed in the corner. They even had UNIQUE outfits and bike colors ffs (d@mn boy (speaking of Early Road Redemption), you gettin yo 4$$ handed to ya by a 20 year old game you tried to surpass). That's right, rival gangs, popo and all that SHARE most of the looks. One surprise I found was that some random racers drove CARS! Wohoo, I can't bash your teeth in but I sure can blow you up with sticky TNT or that nice 40mm launcher.

Then again, the basic get up in the classic was a helmet, a two colored bodysuit, and the color of your bike. The popo had fat bikes and leather with an open helmet so you could see their faces when punching them off their bikes. This one surprises me.
Nobody wears helmets (only random ♥♥♥♥♥ drivers wear those), everyone is beating everyone of different color, the cars just run into you when you try to slow down, Coppers don't play it save, the cars do incredible amounts of colateral damage, the police is more interested in murdering than in real life minus the use of guns (would be too OP I guess).

What I am trying to say here is that basically I like some of the new stuff but laugh at the lack of detail that's been put in the visuals and the behaviour. Everyone is bat$H!T insane and the truck drivers are dropping deadly logs on purpose causing endless waves of crashing cars and taking you off your bike (I guess those things get nerfed sooner or later). It makes the feels go away and make way to a different kind of frustrating. Needs way more polish guys.

One example in combat dynamics:
Here only the toughest makes it out alive (most of the time it is you because everybody else gets knocked the EFF out from one hit criticals or quick 2 hit combos or simply mowed down by gunfire thank god it isn't autoaiming like in some other bike racing games *cough* Jacked *cough*). Once you manage to crash enough times (mostly thrice) then it is bye bye and you gotta restart your career in a parallel universe as the Game Over screen keeps tellin yo stOopid @$$ (or spend EXP on a NEW" concept of advancing the plot. Yes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is really fun. Very addicting. Ive been playing it for quite a while even before it came to steam and i have seen a lot of improvements to it. Its still quite buggy and a lot of things dont make any sense to me but it sure is a blast. The crashes are kind of amazing. The graphics are nice. The music is sort of so so. Sometimes its elevator music and sometimes its hard rock. It plays sort of like a rouge like game. The missions are somewhat random and you have one life to get to the end of the game. At the end of each level you have some time to buy health and pther upgrades with the money you earned in the previous event. Once you die, you can spend some experience points on permanent upgrades that will help you in your next attempt. I have yet to beat it but im getting pretty far now. Its hard to stop playing once you have started. I cant wait to play this with friends. It really does bring back old road rash memories.

I very much recommend this game. Even in its broken state of early access its still a very enjoyable game. Get it on a sale and have a blast.
