reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road Redemption is based on a documentary of one man's crusade to protest the over-hunting of the majestic butterfly whales. Disgusted by humanity's rapacious slaughter of those beautiful creatures, he determined that the only way to impact positive change was to stage a sit-in protest in front of the White House. This game covers the cross-continental journey from the dazzling west coast to the seat of corruption.

Along the way, the young man makes shocking discoveries. The most unsettling is the realization of his own innate violent desires. Unsure how to reconcile them with his noble mission, he lashes out at many bikers who are pursuing their own goals on the lonely roads. The entire time, he is haunted by a semi -- clearly a metaphor for his unstoppable ambition and the pain and destruction it leaves in its wake. His days are filled with explosions, bludgeoned heads, and ragdoll bodies. Eventually, as he nears DC, he comes to a dramatic revelation: Drugs are bad for you. I mean, seriously, what the hell is a butterfly whale?" What was he smoking when he came up with that?

EDIT: I learned I was in contravention of international law ("All endangered species shall be described as 'majestic'). I profusely apologize and have undergone penance (a 24-hour Discovery Channel marathon)."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road redemption is a game available on steam for Early access and while the game is not fully complete, I feel it is the closest thing you will get to a more modern Road Rash game.
EA has a track record of killing off their companies like Westwood and Maxis.
So as far as hopes of a decent Road Rash being put on any other platform besides the Genesis or Windows 98 is probably a lost hope.
Thankfully Road Redemption seems to be one of the better attempts.
While the game is a more pricey indie title, if you are interested in Motorcycle combat games, this is right down your alley.
The game is developed by several individuals -Developer: Dark Seas Interactive , The Fisch Brothers , Pixel Dash Studios , Fish Factory Games
Early access means this game is going to offer consistant updates until a finished product, but currently at this time the game supports achievements, controllers, and new game + modes which allow the continual playing of the game.
Fun at it’s core, Road Redmption hardly can be considered a hard core story driven game.
The game features a few different charecters including a Shovel Knight skin, but that is all they are just skins.
The difficulty determines the speed of the game and damage values, but I found the default to be just fine.
Playing through the beginning of the game is pretty simple, albeit a bit more difficult depending on the level, later on  the difficulty does crank up though.
The player can invest in upgrades while going through the game, but only while playing, once it’s game over all the money used for perment upgrades and XP is lost.
There are also standard upgrades for level to level use like extra life’s, damage, or healing damage.
Weapons are a bigger part of this game than the actual bikes honestly, though most of them are identicle from the pipe to the sword, they really almost feel the same.
Guns are available in the game and take a huge learning curve to learn, aiming and shooting is difficult to say the least, but the most effective way of dealing with enemies.
Cops and other drivers make an appearance as well, and attempt to chance the player down at any given chance.
Random crashes do occur frequently and can throw you off your game often, making it difficult to just race and have fun.
Overall though, the game is fun and grants multiple levels to play through as of now.
I am also told multiplayer will be coming soon as well.
I would recommend this game to anyone familiar with Road Rash or racing games in general, but not to anyone who is un interested in violent games.
I hope you guys enjoyed this review, and I am signing out.
Good Gaming and God Bless!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is just plain FUN!  It not only harkens back to Road Rash, but all the arcade games that were easy to get into and gave you that thrill, whether you beat it or it beat you.  You'll notice I haven't played much so far but even if it never gets out of EA, I feel I've gotten my money's worth.  As an aging gamer, my hand-eye is far from what it used to be so I really stink at this game. I can't even get to 3rd place and die more than I survive but I keep going back for more.  To me, that's the mark of a great game.  I've basically moved into walking simulators, point-and-click adventures, and The Long Dark, but I will be re-energizing my heart with this arcade gem in between.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a little kid, the Road Rash games made we want to travel...and maybe bash people with chains a bit, but I loved the sense of freedom and power. Road Redemption does a million things better than those games from two decades ago, but also has yet to unlock that sense of agency and independence.

What has me writing my review today is that the project has been receiving a lot of attention from its developer over the past several weeks with a constant stream of updates that add content and improve gameplay. The developer is clearly putting a lot of heart into making this a classic, and I want to add my voice in getting it the attention it deserves.

The Good:
Bonkers races that just don't appear in other racing games
Modern graphics
Attacks include kicks, grabs, firearms, timebombs, and a slew of melee weapons from makeshift to medieval
RPG character unlocks & between-race buff shop
Bathooks
Gamepad support

The Bad:
Almost no control over races or progression
You pick your bike at the start of a game and you ride it until you die
Autos' behavior is almost always erratic and sometimes inexplicable (driving off bridges, into cliffs, etc.)

Crazy races, an array of weapons, gamepad support and constantly improving gameplay make this a title I keep coming back to play rather than just wait for it to all be finished.

There are a lot of problems with this game.  The physics doesn't feel right, there are a fair few glitches and the levels get repetitive fast.

That being said there is something about the gameplay that keeps drawing me back for more.  Every time I smash an opponent off their bick or kick them into oncoming traffic I break out in the same little grin I got from Road Rash all those years go.

Replace those horrible roof top races with a dirt bike track and give me a chain and you would have a cracking good game.  In the mean time it's a fun little time waster and I give it a thumbs up.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAbsolutely Cracking. Just finished my 1st play-through and i'm very impressed. Obviously it was a little short but in open access I expect little compromises. It's a very familiar pattern to Road Rash of old with level after level of wild tracks to race. It can be quite seat of the pants type stuff at times with clever dips and rises hiding oncoming traffic, crazy debris spinning about the track, suicidal cop cars etc etc etc. It has a great structure of purchase based add-ons and experience based ones to fine tune your rider for the oncoming challenges but could really use the same to customise and personalise your bike itself. At this time, it could definitely still do with some fine tuning (for example Road Rash's agonisingly long run back to the bike after crashing would add a greater price for recklessness) but all complaints are minimal to the joy you'll get watching a man you've just kicked into oncoming traffic get wiped out by a logging truck. If it was a bigger full game with competitive online multiplayer and the tweaks ironed out it'd be a certain 8 or 9 out of ten. Great work bringing back a sorely missed classic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just finished the Early Access game, holy cow was I impressed! First, the game looks amazing.  Second of all, I felt like I was 5 years old playing the Classic Road Rash, but this game is balls to the wall fast, 99% faster then what I expected, the missions are somewhat difficult, but don't worry if you fail them... You can still continue but without the cash reward at the end of the race. And also, give that number a call! Ian is a very nice man. Didn't mind me calling him at quarter to four in the morning to dicuss the game! (I called thinking it was just a computer recording)

Thoughout my play through of the game I've only had the game crash on me twice, which is not bad, the error reports are sent when you relaunch the game. The Missions are a little repitive but still none the less pretty difficult, and the controlls are SOLID (I perfer using the gamepad, but use the keyboard and mouse if you want to use the guns, and rifles)

10/10 would HIGHLY reccommend if you want a casual, hardcore arcade-ish feeling racing game!

A few things I would LOVE to see in the final build of the game....

Bike customization, Story line, few cutscenes here and there, and more areas to play!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Upon making this review I've only played (about) 3 hours. The Road Redemption team asked if I'd like a free copy to play to provide feedback so here's what I think so far.

Again, like I said, I've only played about 3 hours and I've already had loads of fun. Road Redemption is a high octane arcade racing combat survival game (definitely a mouthful). There's no story or voice acting but the gameplay is all you need. Race across rooftops, take out rivals, taunt the cops and try your best to stay alive. That may sound simple but it's challenging. The AI isn't dumb. They've kicked me off of bridges and have blocked my attacks quite a lot. Cars ram into you and trucks drop lumber and destroy anything in their path. The devs made the braking system really soft so you can't easily dodge grenades or attacks being launched at you. Some missions will have raining cars and random ones that will drive completely horizontal to the highway making it even more challenging and random.

Of course this game being in early access there are still kinks to work out. I've gotten stuck on terrain and sometimes the hit boxes can be a little off. At times I'll find that respawning on the track I can't move and am forced to quit and their secret racing map seems to end in the middle with no finish so I haven't been able to complete the campaign yet. Online mutliplayer hasn't been released yet but if you have a friend you can play local co-op.

To provide some ideas I would definitely add some voice acting and police sirens. It would also be really cool to have a story along with the campaign to make it more immersive and since it's already crazy...why not add a mission where you have to outrun a ridiculously giant truck along with having to deal with your usual rivals? I'm sure you guys must have lots of ideas and I can't wait to see them in action. Overall, I would definitely recommend this game and I can't wait for more content.
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Type of Game:

Action Motorcycle Racing

Version Played:

PC version through Steam

Similar Games:

Road Rash and to a lesser degree Destruction Derby

The Good:

Fast and furious violent action using an assortment of weapons.
Weapons include melee weapons (swords, axes, bats and so forth) and firearms (shotguns, pistols, machine guns and my personal favorite the grenade launcher).
Levels will keep you on your toes with lots of different way to knock you off your bike such as cars, rival bikers and logs dropping of trucks and that’s just on the road.
Shop in-between levels to boost ammo, health, nitro, durability of melee weapons, and much more. Be warned that these upgrades disappear after you lose all your health on the road.
There is persistent experience generation (from killing rival bikers and destroying cars) that allows you to get points to spend upgrading your bike, max health, upgrading your starting weapons, and so forth. These bonuses always stay with you no matter how many times you restart a level.
Split screen campaign (soon to be online). Works very well with shared bonuses from the shop and also a competitive mode is in the works too.
At the time of writing there has been 6 updates to knock out bugs, increase performance and add new content and the game hasn’t been out a month yet, so yes dear reader this is a dev team that listens to its community and keeps an eye out for bugs.

The Bad:

There are no key-bindings just yet (there is a placeholder in the options) so just a head’s up if you don’t have a game-pad. You will struggle without one.
Aiming your cross-hair to use firearms is very difficult and there isn’t a button to reset your camera. What ends up happening is after you try aiming and want to have your camera dead center you need to do it manually and fast before you go head first into a car. I have faith in the dev team that this is going to be sorted out sooner rather than later.
The hit detection seems a bit off from the rival bikers as there able to hit you when they’re in mid air and you’re on the ground, although it seems to happen more on “the rooftop” levels then in the other levels.

Nitpicking:

Yes Road Redemption has bugs, a fair few to put mildly, but only just a few weeks old on Steam and they’ve already released several patches to address the big ones.

Did I make time to complete it?

Yes. 5 times so far in 11 hours.

Redlight or Greenlight:

This game is currently at a greenlight.

Thanks to the dev team for handing out plenty of patches in a short amount of time (big company’s take note). I was a kickstarter backer paying $20, but it was money well spent and I’d gladly spend double if not more for this great title. I’m really, really glad its this team (Dark Seas Games) that has made RR and by the time this has released in its final form it’ll be an instant classic and definitely my game of the year. Can you tell I’m biased towards Road Rash style games?

Reviewer:

Beefy

A Quick Look at Those Games You Might Buy
http://www.gamersglance.com

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's hard to write about a game in Early Access, but I'll give it a shot:
Let me first start out by saying that I would highly recommend this game for those who love racing, but with a bit of violence. These games might incluede: Twisted Metal, Road Rash, Burnout series, and possibly Flatout.

At it's core, the racing mechanics are there, but the aren't heavily influenced by anything other than get from point A to point B. It's more about the journey, not about the destination, and boy is this journey a hell of a lot of fun.

Each mach has different demands: race, destroy, or sometimes you'll find just surviving is a demand in itself. There's just enough nuance in the game to really warrant a purchase.

I actually just got off the phone with the developer (he seems like a really nice guy, and his phone number is actually in the game), and he's stated that they have a lot planned. Hopefully the racing portion become more of its own beast, but time will tell.

I mentioned the journey, getting from point A to point B, and that's where the game shines with all sorts of carnage, explosions, and parrying. There's nothing quite as satisfying as the combat in this game. At it's core it's more a combat racer than it is one or the other, but it does have a heavier emphasis on combat. It's a blast, and co-op will be riot.

That all being said, the game is difficult, like, extremely so; however, it's never to the point of irritation, but more to the point of, Let's play again."

TL;DR

The game's a blast
date: and is a fun combat racing game
recommended: though there is definitely more emphasis on the combat."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road Redemption fits squarely in the Road Rash successor category. A seat that has been collecting dust for far too long IMHO. It also reminds me of the craziness of the Burnout series and Radikal Bikers. I tend to prefer racing games that are more than just racing. Sometimes its more satisfying to just blow it all up. I find this game to be a great way to get all my commuter frustrations out. I'll happily sacrifice realism for entertainment value.

Minor stuff:
The gameplay is pretty solid for an Early Access. Haven't run into any sort of game ending glitches or crashes.
The Punk Model: the skin on his shoulders stretches all kinds of funny when he swings a weapon.
I'm reluctantly happy there isn't a restart race/round option, far too many times I've had awful starts that resulted in a win where I was just trying to finish.
Ballerina Effect: Every once in a while a car or piece of wood will start to spin out and, I guess, lose it's horizontal drag making it spin faster and faster. I kinda like the effect, it definitely has a place in a crazy game like this. It's a mechanic that jives with an icy track or low gravity but not every environment.
Low Speed Turning: I tend to hit the fence on the Star Road from time to time. It usually spins me 180 degrees. I find it easier to select 'put me back on track' instead of attempting to turn around. The turning radius is wider than the track forcing me to make a 3 or 4 point turn just to get reoriented.
Pipe Bomb Bikers: So satisfying to take these guys out. There's a good chance I'm probably just complaining here but in Campaign+ I've run out of time on take-down missions because the Pipe Bomb Bikers take out the other bikers before I can catch them. It isn't a recurring issue, usually happens if I'm out of Nitro.
Campaign+: I found some of the races where there's car rain, bomb guys and car/truck opponents (usually around 10+) were easier to finish because the obstacles end up taking out all the competition in the duration of the race.
Star Road: I found that if I rocket boost right at the sart of the race, before the first drop, I will sometimes fall through the track instead of landing.

Some terrible suggestions:
1) Selectable 10-speed bike: C'mon its a little funny.
2) Female Racer: While Shovel Knight was the addition that made me buy the game, your welcome. I wouldn't be opposed to some sort of female character model.
3) Grab Breaks: Opponents don't seem to break a grab no matter how long I hold them.
4) Intersections: Pretty self explanatory.

Thanks for this gem of a game. Can't wait for the full release.
voteText: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclosure: Received review copy

edit: A couple of patches has been released since this review and most of the issues has been fixed. gameplay has been altered a lot and xp system is now working properly. i have not seen any clipping problems either or crashes.  Opponents tend to home in on you more and difficulty has been slightly increased later on but this is all good as balance is better early game. Upgrades mean a lot to you late game. All in all this is now easily 8 or 9/10 now.


Shortly this game is a 7/10 In it's current state and already a pretty solid recommendation. It is however a game in early access and has potential for a much higher score after some alterations to the game. So lets list the good and the bad:

Good:
- So how many Sega Road Rash -type of games have you seen lately? In 2015 the concept is looking quite fresh.
- Good action. Satisfying violence.  Speed!
- Experience points that can be distributed to skills permanently.
- Experience points that can be used to get upgrades that are in effect until you die.

Bad:
- This is one of those games where the AI is right behind you and if you make a mistake late on a course it's all over in a blink.  Luckily some mistakes are allowed if you are not that far into a race and your hitpoints allow you to continue.
- Random nature of the maps underscores the importance of luck sometimes quite a lot unfortunately. It is common to grind one level a long time until that one time the stars are aligned correctly and you clear it flawlessly.
- Bugs, glitches. Not that many and not that critical. But railings on the bridge are very bugged as they are there pretty much just for show. Also the ground under bridges are the best places to make the game glitch so bad you fall trought the ground into the void.
- It is possible to stop from full speed to zero in an instant and get stuck on things near the road or civilian cars that drive on the road. I was not amused when i got hooked on a car for a long time unable to get off. Quit button solved that one.
- Restart button missing. Essential function in any racing game. Put on the Road -button is there but it's not the same nor does it work most of the time until you are very deep outside the road. (and guaranteed to loose the race at that point).
- Experience point system could use a closer look. Loosing all XP in certain situations ensure there is extra grind that does not help. Even keeping small amounts of XP after every game would help.

Road Redemption is refreshed old Road Rash on Mega Drive and Play Station. It has all what we loved in these games: tons of adrenaline and madness, hi-speed fights and destruction (hoping of some wild life in the future of RR).
But there is some new stuff:
- firearms (AK47 and M79 Blooper are taste so good!),
- races across rooftops (use jump jets and grapple helicopters with a harpoon),
- and finally - ride a rainbow!

So, if someone hasn't decided yet - remove all doubts and buy!

PS And try to imagine yourself ride the bike while shooting with a lever action shotgun (just like in Terminator 2 movie) in truck carrying logs (Final Destination 2) to release them right on your opponents... That's awesome!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAbsolutely Cracking. Just finished my 1st play-through and i'm very impressed. Obviously it was a little short but in open access I expect little compromises. It's a very familiar pattern to Road Rash of old with level after level of wild tracks to race. It can be quite seat of the pants type stuff at times with clever dips and rises hiding oncoming traffic, crazy debris spinning about the track, suicidal cop cars etc etc etc. It has a great structure of purchase based add-ons and experience based ones to fine tune your rider for the oncoming challenges but could really use the same to customise and personalise your bike itself. At this time, it could definitely still do with some fine tuning (for example Road Rash's agonisingly long run back to the bike after crashing would add a greater price for recklessness) but all complaints are minimal to the joy you'll get watching a man you've just kicked into oncoming traffic get wiped out by a logging truck. If it was a bigger full game with competitive online multiplayer and the tweaks ironed out it'd be a certain 8 or 9 out of ten. Great work bringing back a sorely missed classic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just finished the Early Access game, holy cow was I impressed! First, the game looks amazing.  Second of all, I felt like I was 5 years old playing the Classic Road Rash, but this game is balls to the wall fast, 99% faster then what I expected, the missions are somewhat difficult, but don't worry if you fail them... You can still continue but without the cash reward at the end of the race. And also, give that number a call! Ian is a very nice man. Didn't mind me calling him at quarter to four in the morning to dicuss the game! (I called thinking it was just a computer recording)

Thoughout my play through of the game I've only had the game crash on me twice, which is not bad, the error reports are sent when you relaunch the game. The Missions are a little repitive but still none the less pretty difficult, and the controlls are SOLID (I perfer using the gamepad, but use the keyboard and mouse if you want to use the guns, and rifles)

10/10 would HIGHLY reccommend if you want a casual, hardcore arcade-ish feeling racing game!

A few things I would LOVE to see in the final build of the game....

Bike customization, Story line, few cutscenes here and there, and more areas to play!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a little kid, the Road Rash games made we want to travel...and maybe bash people with chains a bit, but I loved the sense of freedom and power. Road Redemption does a million things better than those games from two decades ago, but also has yet to unlock that sense of agency and independence.

What has me writing my review today is that the project has been receiving a lot of attention from its developer over the past several weeks with a constant stream of updates that add content and improve gameplay. The developer is clearly putting a lot of heart into making this a classic, and I want to add my voice in getting it the attention it deserves.

The Good:
Bonkers races that just don't appear in other racing games
Modern graphics
Attacks include kicks, grabs, firearms, timebombs, and a slew of melee weapons from makeshift to medieval
RPG character unlocks & between-race buff shop
Bathooks
Gamepad support

The Bad:
Almost no control over races or progression
You pick your bike at the start of a game and you ride it until you die
Autos' behavior is almost always erratic and sometimes inexplicable (driving off bridges, into cliffs, etc.)

Crazy races, an array of weapons, gamepad support and constantly improving gameplay make this a title I keep coming back to play rather than just wait for it to all be finished.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road Redemption fits squarely in the Road Rash successor category. A seat that has been collecting dust for far too long IMHO. It also reminds me of the craziness of the Burnout series and Radikal Bikers. I tend to prefer racing games that are more than just racing. Sometimes its more satisfying to just blow it all up. I find this game to be a great way to get all my commuter frustrations out. I'll happily sacrifice realism for entertainment value.

Minor stuff:
The gameplay is pretty solid for an Early Access. Haven't run into any sort of game ending glitches or crashes.
The Punk Model: the skin on his shoulders stretches all kinds of funny when he swings a weapon.
I'm reluctantly happy there isn't a restart race/round option, far too many times I've had awful starts that resulted in a win where I was just trying to finish.
Ballerina Effect: Every once in a while a car or piece of wood will start to spin out and, I guess, lose it's horizontal drag making it spin faster and faster. I kinda like the effect, it definitely has a place in a crazy game like this. It's a mechanic that jives with an icy track or low gravity but not every environment.
Low Speed Turning: I tend to hit the fence on the Star Road from time to time. It usually spins me 180 degrees. I find it easier to select 'put me back on track' instead of attempting to turn around. The turning radius is wider than the track forcing me to make a 3 or 4 point turn just to get reoriented.
Pipe Bomb Bikers: So satisfying to take these guys out. There's a good chance I'm probably just complaining here but in Campaign+ I've run out of time on take-down missions because the Pipe Bomb Bikers take out the other bikers before I can catch them. It isn't a recurring issue, usually happens if I'm out of Nitro.
Campaign+: I found some of the races where there's car rain, bomb guys and car/truck opponents (usually around 10+) were easier to finish because the obstacles end up taking out all the competition in the duration of the race.
Star Road: I found that if I rocket boost right at the sart of the race, before the first drop, I will sometimes fall through the track instead of landing.

Some terrible suggestions:
1) Selectable 10-speed bike: C'mon its a little funny.
2) Female Racer: While Shovel Knight was the addition that made me buy the game, your welcome. I wouldn't be opposed to some sort of female character model.
3) Grab Breaks: Opponents don't seem to break a grab no matter how long I hold them.
4) Intersections: Pretty self explanatory.

Thanks for this gem of a game. Can't wait for the full release.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI’m the type of guy that to this day still has my Sega Genesis with Road Rash hooked up to my Television, so when I learned about Road Redemption it was an instant buy for me. When I first started playing, I was a little leery, as it is so clearly early access. The models aren’t the best (especially the collision models); it’s poorly optimized, there are no key re-bindings… but above all, it’s still a blast to play. The level design is great, the combat system is like Road Rash on steroids, the weapon selection is massive ( who doesn’t love taking someone out with a claymore, mace, or harpoon gun?), and the developers actually care about feedback. For a measly $12 I got to spend a night with my best friend barreling through deserts, forests, and rooftops all while beating and shooting our way to victory. The game still has a long way to go before it’s finished, but the concept is solid and the team is obviously dedicated to making a great game. I highly recommend it, even in its current state.

date: but the opening levels seem rather short.\n\nThe least "road rashy" thing about this game so far is the use of guns and bombs
recommended: though that's not entirely a bad thing.  It's great fun to ride up next to someone
hoursPlayed: tag them with C4 and then ride away as they blow up.  It's also great fun to raise the cop level by going on a gun rampage.  So far though
voteText:
these are extremely powerful and should be something you achieve by doing something awesome (like maybe causing a 5 bike pileup or booting the lead racer off a bridge).

Kicking bikes and hitting them with pipes so far reminds me A LOT of the original Road Rash game.  That game made you work to achieve a weapon though (usually by grabbing it out of the hands of someone else) whereas this game gives you a weapon right at the start.  I think I preferred earning the weapon through gameplay.

Some of the racing aspects of the game seem like it needs work.  Making turns doesn't feel as good as it should

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The best and most promising thing I've seen to come from Early Access.
I love the Road Rash style combat mixed with the over the top environments the game has to offer.
You'll find yourself racing in raining cars or on top of skyscrapers, all while kicking and pushing others off the track.
It's very addicting and satisfying racing/combat.
Only real issue I had was that in the mayhem of the game the FPS would dip on my high end card.

My ideas on things to add:
I would like to see some customization for the vehicle/player
A Custom Race option would be nice too

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Combines the most amazing racing gaming experience, with great graphics and extraordinary physics. On top of that you add the maps you always wanted to play in racing games, like jumping buildings, roads with bridges and deserts with ramps! Plus super exciting modes, it's not just racing, it's also killing and shooting other people, police and racers on the road, rocket launchers, huges axes, katanas and C4s? Heck yeah.

Very competitive, you will never get bored, both multiplayer and singleplayer. It gets addictive to complete more and more levels each time. It's also not an easy game, requires skills, focus on the road and various items at the same time. An instant favorite for sure.

With a very responsive and friendly dev team.

Totally worth it for everyone. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played a lot of games in my life, but few can match the fun of putting the beatdown on a rider while weaving through head-on traffic and bumping others into road hazards.  It NEVER gets old.

Like most others, I loved Road Rash, and was thrilled to see this game in development.  As it turns out, the game thus far is both a fun-as-hell Mad Max-esque racing game AND a wonderful trip down memory lane.  This game is spot on with the feel and spirit of Road Rash, so if that's why you're here, it's mission accomplished.

I look forward to the future game modes, improvements and surprises that Road Redemption has in store for everyone.

8.5/10 -- 8/10 for Early Access, plus 0.5 for raining cars.

There are a lot of problems with this game.  The physics doesn't feel right, there are a fair few glitches and the levels get repetitive fast.

That being said there is something about the gameplay that keeps drawing me back for more.  Every time I smash an opponent off their bick or kick them into oncoming traffic I break out in the same little grin I got from Road Rash all those years go.

Replace those horrible roof top races with a dirt bike track and give me a chain and you would have a cracking good game.  In the mean time it's a fun little time waster and I give it a thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Disclosure: Received review copy

edit: A couple of patches has been released since this review and most of the issues has been fixed. gameplay has been altered a lot and xp system is now working properly. i have not seen any clipping problems either or crashes.  Opponents tend to home in on you more and difficulty has been slightly increased later on but this is all good as balance is better early game. Upgrades mean a lot to you late game. All in all this is now easily 8 or 9/10 now.


Shortly this game is a 7/10 In it's current state and already a pretty solid recommendation. It is however a game in early access and has potential for a much higher score after some alterations to the game. So lets list the good and the bad:

Good:
- So how many Sega Road Rash -type of games have you seen lately? In 2015 the concept is looking quite fresh.
- Good action. Satisfying violence.  Speed!
- Experience points that can be distributed to skills permanently.
- Experience points that can be used to get upgrades that are in effect until you die.

Bad:
- This is one of those games where the AI is right behind you and if you make a mistake late on a course it's all over in a blink.  Luckily some mistakes are allowed if you are not that far into a race and your hitpoints allow you to continue.
- Random nature of the maps underscores the importance of luck sometimes quite a lot unfortunately. It is common to grind one level a long time until that one time the stars are aligned correctly and you clear it flawlessly.
- Bugs, glitches. Not that many and not that critical. But railings on the bridge are very bugged as they are there pretty much just for show. Also the ground under bridges are the best places to make the game glitch so bad you fall trought the ground into the void.
- It is possible to stop from full speed to zero in an instant and get stuck on things near the road or civilian cars that drive on the road. I was not amused when i got hooked on a car for a long time unable to get off. Quit button solved that one.
- Restart button missing. Essential function in any racing game. Put on the Road -button is there but it's not the same nor does it work most of the time until you are very deep outside the road. (and guaranteed to loose the race at that point).
- Experience point system could use a closer look. Loosing all XP in certain situations ensure there is extra grind that does not help. Even keeping small amounts of XP after every game would help.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road redemption is a game available on steam for Early access and while the game is not fully complete, I feel it is the closest thing you will get to a more modern Road Rash game.
EA has a track record of killing off their companies like Westwood and Maxis.
So as far as hopes of a decent Road Rash being put on any other platform besides the Genesis or Windows 98 is probably a lost hope.
Thankfully Road Redemption seems to be one of the better attempts.
While the game is a more pricey indie title, if you are interested in Motorcycle combat games, this is right down your alley.
The game is developed by several individuals -Developer: Dark Seas Interactive , The Fisch Brothers , Pixel Dash Studios , Fish Factory Games
Early access means this game is going to offer consistant updates until a finished product, but currently at this time the game supports achievements, controllers, and new game + modes which allow the continual playing of the game.
Fun at it’s core, Road Redmption hardly can be considered a hard core story driven game.
The game features a few different charecters including a Shovel Knight skin, but that is all they are just skins.
The difficulty determines the speed of the game and damage values, but I found the default to be just fine.
Playing through the beginning of the game is pretty simple, albeit a bit more difficult depending on the level, later on  the difficulty does crank up though.
The player can invest in upgrades while going through the game, but only while playing, once it’s game over all the money used for perment upgrades and XP is lost.
There are also standard upgrades for level to level use like extra life’s, damage, or healing damage.
Weapons are a bigger part of this game than the actual bikes honestly, though most of them are identicle from the pipe to the sword, they really almost feel the same.
Guns are available in the game and take a huge learning curve to learn, aiming and shooting is difficult to say the least, but the most effective way of dealing with enemies.
Cops and other drivers make an appearance as well, and attempt to chance the player down at any given chance.
Random crashes do occur frequently and can throw you off your game often, making it difficult to just race and have fun.
Overall though, the game is fun and grants multiple levels to play through as of now.
I am also told multiplayer will be coming soon as well.
I would recommend this game to anyone familiar with Road Rash or racing games in general, but not to anyone who is un interested in violent games.
I hope you guys enjoyed this review, and I am signing out.
Good Gaming and God Bless!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game combines a motorcycle racing game with the unfettered love of violence that is Hotline Miami. Add to that the seemingly randomness of the courses and free for all wacky physics of many sandbox simulators and you get Road Redemption. This game is a guilty pleasure of mine whenever I need to unwind. Fire it up and just start attacking and destroying random drivers and motorcyclists.

One of the great features is the ability to earn XP so even if you die often (as i do) you still get to progress through the game. I can't wait to see where they take this game.

Full disclosure I got this game through their Kickstarter campaign, but I had almost forgot that by the time the game was actually available. Not sure how my opinion would change if I wasn't part of the campaign.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I LOVE THIS GAME. This is the Road Rash remake I always begged for but even better! The visuals are really smooth and look great. It handles like a dream. It's all the fun of the Burnout series, the concept of the Road Rash series, but it seriously outshines both franchises with how fun it is.

Maybe this has just been a long time coming but I can see myself playing this game for days on end. I'm so happy I bought it full price. This is an early access title you won't regret buying.

The only real con I have with the game so far is that the camera controls can be a little wonky at times. If it were more automated movement (as in it followed you around) it would be ideal. This is a really small/minor complaint though. The controls are sooo, so fluid and work very well. It's unreal how fun this game is. I can't recommend it enough. I only want to see more and I'll pay more dollars to support it.

Early Access Review

This game is still in Early Access, so be aware that it contains several bugs and it is constantly changing until it'll reach it's final form. However, the devs are releasing updates quite frequently (every 2-3 days) and they're taking seriously the customers' responses and actively participating in the forum too.

This game is a motorcycle-action game, similar to the old Road Rash games, but in a modern form and improved with several great ideas. The graphics is beautiful and meets all modern requirements a game needs today. The controls are very responsive, and easy to get used to it, however you'll need both your hands, because the action buttons are on the mouse (if you play it with keyboard and mouse of course).

There are several game modes" (inside campaign and campaign+ and competitive is coming too) and those are varying map by map

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A brutal racing game with a large arsenal of all kinds of weapons at your disposal.

Still missing a lot of features like multiplayer, but the singleplayer campaign has a decent amount of variety to keep you hooked. You gain experience as you play, which can be used to unlock new abilities or bonuses. During the games you can also gain cash to use for temporary upgrades that you lose upon death.

As it is still in early access, you have to expect a lot of bugs and glitches. Have only seen a game breaking glitch once so far that forced me to restart the game. Smaller ones like being able to fire a gun after you are knocked out, flying in the air, even while not even holding it.

Pro:
- Great soundtrack (though somewhat repetitive).
- Lots of different weapons and tools to choose from.
- Decent AI
- Responsive & good controls

Con:
- Lack of vehicle variety
- Still in a glitchy state (expecting it to be a lot better in time)
- Lack of online multiplater yet (This game would really benefit from a multiplayer mode soon)

Game tries to be a Road Rash successor, but for now it sucks massive dícks and Road Rash is way superior.

Physics are total crap. All bikes are pieces of wet soap sliding on a glass lake.

If this is still in development, many issues can be excused. Except physics.
Either it is set up more or less realistically from the start or nobody will invest time fixing it later.

It would be a mediocre game in 2006.
In 2016... I don't even know.

Kinda painful to see a good modern engine like unity powering up such mostrosity.

Music is good though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a big fan of the Road Rash series (Road Rash 3 in particular), I really really want to like this game. My friend and I played this on splitscreen for about two and a half hours, but we never felt invested like in the old games. Nothing we did felt particularly meaningful, starting with the character select screen where we had to pick identical characters and bikes. The way the races end is incredibly jarring. As soon as one player crosses the finish line, the level just ends. The second player cannot finish the race, there's no fan-fare, no overview of the race, and no trash-talking bikers. Also, none of the levels feel very distinct from one another. No kangaroos jumping out at you or hitch hikers to run over. Just a generic weaving three-lane highway that seems to loop back on itself ad nauseum (on account of proceedural generated levels, the geography of this game is kinda messed up). The upgrade system feels meaningless as well. You can choose from a number of boxes with static bonuses, as opposed to RR3 where it was all about saving up for that sweet new bike, then decking out the tires and suspension. Jumps also don't do much. In RR3 you'd go off a jump and fly off the f-ing screen. In this there's barely any air or any other real reason to hit a jump. The weapon degradation system is similarly meaningless. You come across weapons so frequently and carry around such a large inventory that you'll never go wanting. In the old games, stealing a pair of nunchucks felt like a huge accomplishment. The police don't do much in this. They won't run you off the road and bust you. They're more there for lip service I guess. I also don't understand why there are so many armed motorcyclists, but only some of them are in the race. I suppose one of my biggest beefs is that the campaign never makes you feel like you're accomplishing anything. In RR3, getting through Japan on level 5 while riding a super bike was a huge feat.

I know the game isn't finished, but I can't really recommend it in its current incarnation. I hope it touches up on some of the areas I've discussed. The combat system is fairly satisfying. Grabbing other riders and driving off cliffs is hilarious. I like the detours. Fighting semi trucks is ♥♥♥♥ed lol. I'd probably be way less critical if I wasn't a huge RR3 fan. Despite my numerous criticisms, I seriously admire what they're trying to do here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have never cursed at a game as much as I have at this one, but it's also the most fun I've had with a game in quite some time. At times it's frustratingly difficult, but that just makes the times you make it through all the more special. I would name myself a jaded gamer, I struggle to find as much joy with games these days. However this little gem of a game has come along and helped me rediscover a bit of gaming joy.

There's a definite feeling of speed, and both the combat and dodging of obstacles can give that on-edge feeling where your breath stops for just a moment as you wait those milliseconds to see if you edged it.

There's rightly a lot of comparisons to Road Rash, but this game stands out on its own merit. It has a whackyness that surpasses the prior game, and the feeling of progression is different as well, at least in this early access edition. Road rash felt more gradual, whereas this game throws you right into things. Said progression is a bit strange in Road Redemption, but it has its own charm if you have the patience.

The game still needs work, there are some strange occurances and the odd crash, but the patches have been coming thick and fast and I am confident it will only get better. It is already an extremely enjoyable game and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2_T0GUjm5yc

VERSION: 0.814

Road Redemption is the spiritual successor to Road Rash, and it's developed by a lot of people.

In Road Redemption, you play as a biker that's going from the East coast to the West coast in a post apocalyptic America. The game is a procedurally generated racing action game. There are multiple types of missions, including takedowns, cop attraction, race against bikers or race against time...

In the game you get a huge arsenal of weapons: baseball bats, pipes, swords, machine guns, grenade launchers, axes...
The driving is really arcady and the attack buttons have to be pressed moments before hitting the opponents, similarly to the whip in Castlevania. The AI works really well, and gets more and more challenging as you go on. In the four areas of the game (desert, rooftops, snowy mountain and a bonus one), there are multiple hazards (like traffic and buildings) or variables (like car rain).

Another great aspect of the game is the soundtrack: it is really energetic and fits the game like a glove.

There are, however, some problems related to the performance: in some tracks, especially the first one, the framerate drops at 6fps. The developer have assured that they are working on fixing these issues.

Overall, this is one of the most action packed racing games I've ever played, it gets constantly updated by the developers and it will feature additional content such as competitive gameplay, character customization and more weapons. One of the best Early Access games to support.

SCORE: 90/100

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access - Jan 18th, 2015 update

Road Redemption is an awesome game if you've been missing the good old Road Rash days. The game has some similarities to Road Rash but has a lot of unique featuers as well, such as vertical jump jets on your bikes in the city rooftop level, and a Just Cause 2 style hook shot thing. The game is also somewhat Roguelike-ish in how it plays, with perma death on your rider, but also letting you upgrade your character for the next attempt.

I've played it before and loaded it up again after multiple updates and found the game is even better than I remember. The graphics are great and with updates the performance issues are greatly improved. The music is fantastic and gets you pumped for kicking ♥♥♥ on the streets, and the sound effects have been improved and are even better now.

Oh yeah, you can race as Shovel Knight now, awesome!

Great variety of weapons, melee as well as guns & even C4. The guns are a little hard to control while trying to maintain your place on the road and not wipe out in a corner or on some ♥♥♥♥♥ driving their car into you, hopefully things improve on the guns and aiming. I'm not really worried though, because every time I go back to play this it has been updated and is even better than before.

Still waiting on the multiplayer, and I think that will be incredible when it comes in.
The game itself is fun to play and even has up to 4 player local co-op, but the campaign still feels a bit lacking. I'm not sure what it is, but it needs something to tie the races together, a story or something.

You are racing and it's great fun, but you don't really know why you are racing, and the levels - while being fun - don't segway into each other and feel like instead of doing a campaign you have to do 10 random levels then do the last level. I am certain this will be address in the final version, and it is still in early access, so we'll just have to wait and see.

All that said, this game is awesome. If you liked Road Rash, and you also like Roguelike games, this is a gooder!
If you're not into early access, than definitely come back and check it out after the full release.

http://youtu.be/uP5QhklnoWs

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing pick up and play arcade-style PC game, and I'd been looking for one of this genre that I liked since I got Steam a year ago... this is the one. It has all the feelings of classic Road Rash (this is coming from a Sega Genesis veteran who by the way was decently disturbed by the violence in the game when I was 4)...

...and this violence is understandably much worse in this modern day game (not in a bad way)... it has a decent amount of blood and a sort of disturbing sound effect when the melee weapon cracks against the body of an opponent. Yes it's disturbing, but it kind of puts a moral urgency on whether or not you want to violently and bloodily slam someone off of their bike and probably maim them for life. But I don't want to make it seem like the violence is overwhelming. It's just enough to be funny and in your face but not overdone.

Immediately fun, easy controls, and it has an interesting old school game path where you progress through levels and if you die you have to start over. Kind of gives you more of an initiative to keep playing, I feel.

Sure I've only played a half hour so I can't know for sure about replayability or longevity, but I'm sure when online multiplayer is released it will be a huge plus, not to mention local split screen co-op which I've also been scarcely pleased with on Steam for a year.

Great game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The controls are a bit sloppy, the graphics are a bit fuzzy, and the physics are certainly not spot on, but damn it, I have fun playing it. Good ol' fashioned video game fun right here folks. I absolutely loved the original Road Rash series, and this makes me smile just like it did. Motorcycles, cattle prods, and grenade launchers...what's not to love?

The developers continue to improve the gameplay, and those sloppy controls/graphics/physics I mentioned are being improved upon as the weeks pass. I just did a playthrough on 7/20/15, and the graphics/controls are definitely better than when I first played the game in February. Everything appears much sharper than before, and it feels a bit more like actually riding a motorcycle. The physics have been made more realistic as well, although there are a few hiccups at times when I'm pretty sure I pass straight through objects. More than anything, I just hope multiplayer gets added (I'd love to have co-op, cracking skulls on motorcycles with a friend? Yes, please).

At this point, it's worth at least a solid 15-20 hours of single player gameplay. Is that worth $20 bucks? For me, yes. If multiplayer ever gets added, I'd absolutely recommend buying it without hesitation.

This is the type of game that makes me question steam's binary review system - you either give thumbs up or thumbs down, neither of which conveys my feelings about this game. Then again, it's still an improvement from steam's old system, which didn't even have a no" option at all!

So
date: on to Road Redemption. This game is a spiritual successor to EA's Road Rash series of games
recommended: so the main game play consists of beating the crap out of your fellow bikers and trying to be the first to the finish line. But this isn't just a re-skin of road rash with modern graphics. Combat is effectively required
hoursPlayed: as some missions flat out require you to eliminate enough enemies to advance. But all the missions (save the pure time trials) require plenty of fighting. Taking down another racer will knock them out of the race
voteText: and taking down almost anyone will restore some health and nitro
helpfulPercent: as well as reward some money and their weapon.\n\nIt's no surprise then
votesHelpful: that the developers took care to make the fighting the single best part of the game. There's a lot of depth to the combat
votesTotal: from kicks and grabs to baseball bats and pistols. Kicks and grabs are good for steering someone into an oncoming car or forcing them off a cliff. Melee weapons vary in speed
votesFunny: strength
commentsCount: and durability - for instance
column16: shovels are strong but slow
column17: while bats are weaker but faster. Swords break easily but are both fast and strong. Then you have the guns
column18: ranging from pistols to Uzis and grenade launchers. They are great for shooting other bikers from a distance. Finally
column19: you can deflect an attack from an enemy - if done right it blocks the attack and makes your next attack very powerful.\n\nThere are various missions and various conditions to preform them under. Most of these are fun
column20: such as eliminataing a certain number of enemies
column21: or attracting police attention. However
column22: the 'time trial' missions lack the fun factor present in the other mission types. They are the only missions with no one to fight
column23: and it seems that there's no reason for these missions to be here
column24: other than "a racing game needs time trials"! Many also cannot stand the 'car rain' missions
column25: where cars literally rain down from the sky and crash into the ground. They'd be pretty fun if it wasn't for the pure randomness of it - it's possible for a car to land right in your way (or otherwise bounce or slide in your wary) with no chance to react
column26: causing an instant crash and a loss of some health.\n\nLosing health is a big deal
column27: because unlike in the road rash games where zero health meant losing a few positions
column28: in Road Redemption it's an instant game over! This is the most drastic departure from the classics
column29: where the only way to lose was inability to pay for your wrecked bike or a ticket form the cops. Death means starting back from square one
column30: except for the skills you purchase with XP
column31: which you get to retain between playthroughs. This isn't necessarily a bad thing
column32: as the skills are fairly neat. But it may tick of long-time rashers who just wanted to relive the classics.\n\nThe game's actual problem lies in it's lack of content. I was able to complete everything this game has to offer within 3.1 hours
column34: the campaign is comprised of 12 levels with randomly generated missions
column35: and there is a harder campaign+ which is the same
column36: just harder. There is no story to speak of
column37: and the only multiplayer is local split-screen co-op. This is what made the game so hard to recommenced - 3.1 hours does not justify the game's $19.99 price tag - even if it were 75% off
column38: that's well over a dollar an hour! So why then
column41: at the top of this review?\n\nMy final recommendation arises not from what this game currently is
column42: but from what it can be in the future. This game's Greenlight page gives a description of a story featuring multiple outcomes depending on your actions
column43: as well as facing betrayal from your gang
column44: and leading your own gang at some point later in the plot. This story mode alone would be worth the price if added to the already outstanding gameplay
column45: but the developer seems to be active in the forums and seems to express a desire to add plenty of other content
column46: and already has added quite a bit since early access release. Based on what this game can become
column47: I ultimately must recommend this game.\n\nI must make sure to revisit this review in the future once the game is completed
column48: whenever that may be.\n\nUPDATE: Road Redemption has undergone an engine change. Historically
column49: an engine change mid development results in classic games like Daikatana and Duke Nukem Forever. Thankfully
column50: this game may be an exception to the rule.\n\nThe boring time trial missions appear to have been removed entirely while the car rain missions (referred in-game as "Hallucinogenic chemical zone") have been altered so that cars are always avoidable. In addition

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I’ll say this about the developers. They know how to take feedback, no matter how negative it is. My first review was extremely negative but not only was I contacted by the devs (like, through Steam chat directly) but they have made many of the changes both I and other critics suggested. The game has gone from Lunacy Racer, which it was originally, to something akin to Road Rash. And you know what? It is a lot of fun. It’s a great Early Access title that really does test your skill and shock you with bone-crunching crashes when that skill fails.

It is still lacking a few elements including context for the missions (why are we trying to raise our Police Wanted Level) and store prices (why does a strip of beef jerky cost $500) but these 'flaws' can be excused as they are still developing the game. And make no mistake – they are developing it. It has come a long way since those early days.

If you are interested in a very violent motorbike racing game full of shocking crashes and satisfying ‘skull-cracking’ combat, this is the game for you. It is A LOT of fun!

This game is a fantastic revamp of the classic road rash series and man have they done a good job. Very addictive, with lots of potential and edge of your seat action.

The controls are very intuitive with what seems like arcade mechanics, on the flip side it only supports standard xbox controllers and keyboard/mouse at present. Would like to see more focus on bike customisation and confirmed date for multiplayer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent game. A very close comparison to Road Rash, which I enjoyed a lot.  It is a extremely frustrating game (expect to die a lot), so this is sort of like Dark Souls on bikes.

It is a satisfying feeling to kick a biker off a bridge, or kick them into oncoming traffic.  I can imagine how the multiplayer would be.

So far, there are more pros than cons.  The only cons that I have are some missing weapons (like the chain, which is iconic to bikers and Road Rash) and glitches, which will be fixed soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game. Oh man. If you loved Road Rash but thought that maybe it could use a bit more variety, maybe a larger assortment of weapons or some different missions besides racing, then you will love this game. This game is an absolute blast.

Bored with hitting other riders with bats? How about a shovel? Or a pipe wrench? Oh, blunt objects not doing it for you? HOW ABOUT A SWORD? Don't want to melee? HOW ABOUT A MACHINE GUN? Not powerful enough? HOW ABOUT A GRENADE LAUNCHER? Or have some C4 and reach into the cars that are trying to take you down (yes, some of your enemies are cars instead of just bikes) and stick some C4 in the passenger seat and watch it explode a few seconds later. You'll have more fun attacking other riders than you ever did before. I hope the developers are also going to allow people to mod custom weapons and maps to provide even more variety.

The difficulty is just challenging enough that the game is fun and easy to grow into but not so easy that it's boring. With so many weapons, it's not easy to master the timing and mechanics of each weapon, and weapon deterioration makes it so you have to learn to use different weapons properly. I struggled a little bit with using the mouse to control the camera while racing, especially around corners. That's not a problem when using a controller, but then trying to aim a gun with the right thumbstick while still controlling the bike properly becomes the challenge. It's difficult, but not something that I didn't noticably improve on after a couple hours of gameplay.

The physics aren't all that realistic, though I don't exactly expect them to be. This is an arcade game and not a strict simulation, and the explosions and crashes are accordingly over the top and cartoonish in the best way. Some of the more nitpicky quirks are that you can avoid a complete wipeout when hitting something (especially on the side of the road) simply by braking or letting off the throttle. You'll just hit something and then stop immediately but not crash. That also applies to big crashes in the middle of the road. I've been sandwiched by two vehicles, but just by not accelerating, I can practically surf the wreckage and leave unscathed. It certainly doesn't bother me as a new player, since I have no problem finding plenty of other ways to wreck myself, but it might become more annoying as I grow into a less idiotic rider.

Maybe this is just personal preference, but I would also like to see some longer maps, and maybe an actual minimap in the corner instead of a progress bar. Driving through the city in Road Rash was also fun, and this was something I didn't see in this game (other than the rooftop map, which is a nice, though sometimes frustrating, addition). I would love to see some maps that mix intracity and intercity roads, but I know the developers are hard at work on a lot of other requests. Tunnels are also another racing game staple that aren't in the game yet that I would love to see. Also, if the developers ever put together some sort of map where the course manages to travel THROUGH some buildings, I might just buy this game for all of my friends who want it (I can dream, can't I?).

Overall, I'm going to be playing a lot of this game, especially as the developers keep adding more to it. It's very well-polished for an early access game, and I can't wait to see what else gets added. I already have a few friends that are itching to play this in online multiplayer, and I can't wait to strap some C4 to their bikes and kick them off the road.

Early Access Review

This game keeps the ol' Road Rash spirit and cranks it up a notch while still being original, highly recommended if you're a fan of the series but keep in mind that this ISN'T Road Rash or a spiritual successor, it is it's own game. It's more extreme than RR, there's guns, explosives and even a harpoon gun and a jetpack, along with the usual array of melee weapons. Hell there's even raining cars!


This game is early access so obviously there's going to be some flaws like the framerate gets a bit choppy when there's a lot of traffic and I've been experiencing a few crashes lately after the latest update but other than that I've been having a blast.

I did run into a glitch where there was a guy on abike next to me at all times, invincible, who looked like he had a severe mental disability. It was great, I named him Timothey. It's not Road Rash, it's something totally different - and I love it. Road Redemption has somehow managed to revive the car combat genre of my teens, around the fundamentals of Road Rash (with some fantastic additions), and included some wild mechanical changes (i.e. raining cars). I am very excited to see what Dark Seas can do with this game.

However, I should point out that the Early Access version that I've played at the time of this review had some problems with framerate (when the level turned especially chaotic).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING: EARLY ACCESS GAME REVIEW

So as the game was released to early access yesterday and as such has plenty of bugs, lack of polish and the game isn't that long  and only consists of a single player campaign currently.

Initially I had difficulties starting the game at all, with it crashing before even loading up. However that only existed for the evening, and the next morning I was able to start playing.

Now I'm not a very good gamer, being honest, and this game offers a respectable challenge. But I've had so much fun already. I've only reached level 6 (not sure how many there are) and once you die,  you have to restart. However it's not as bad as it seems. After each successful level you get cash to spend on extra weapons, food and the like. Cash and purchased items only last until you die. When you die you get experience earned to spend on permanent upgrades. These include extra health, more weapon durablity/ammunition and extra lives etc. There's a decent sized tech tree to unlock. So each time you fail you're made a little stronger for the next attempt.

If you've played Road Rash then you're familiar with the style of play; fast-action racing with lots of cars and other bikers, all kicking, punching and smacking each other over the road (and over cliffs as well) trying to win the race. There are also guns and explosions, cars flying everywhere, enemy police bikes/cars and other car racers fighting you, taxis on skyscraper rooves and I'm sure some of the ambient traffic tries to take you out too!

The devs have named some of the enemy bikers after popular youtubers/streamers such as TotalBiscuit, Pewdiepie and Spoony, which I chuckled at.

Now of course there are bugs (had one where I levitated at the side of a building after falling over the edge) and in general it lacks polish. The devs have promised a competitive multiplayer/pvp mode at launch, which should be fun... though I'll die instantly probably!

All in all, you can replay the same few levels over n over and have a lot of fun. It's not a game you'll be able to play for thousands of hours unless you're really good at the pvp mode, but you'll certainly get your money's worth for just £14, and once completed, it'll be something I come back to every now and again for a quick blast of fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

More satisfying then Sniper Elite

Did you ever play Road Rash? Did you like it? If so then this game is for you. Buy it immediately.

This game takes Road Rash, a motorcycle racing game with violence, gives it more modern graphics, and then kicks it up a few notches. It's got all the basics. Bludgeoning your enemies, kicking them into oncoming traffic, grabbing them and forcing them into obstacles, shooting them, etc. All your normal, violent, motorcycle race needs. But that's just the beginning.

A few levels in you might experience cars dropping from the sky. Why? Hell if I know. But man does it cause a lot of destruction. On level 4 your bike gets Jump Jets. Congratulations, you can now jump several dozen feet in the air. Sound crazy? It's not. Mostly it's just useful. It's also fun as hell. Beginning on Level 5 you start racing across skyscraper rooftops, and yes, it's as fun as it sounds. More fun in fact because you get a grappling hook that allows you to swing your way to victory. The only downside is that it's a bit hard to use. But when you do use it, man do you soar through the air.

And it just keeps going. The current last level is fantastic. I shall refrain from spoiling it and just say that it is a racing game classic and everyone will get a kick out of it. Or hate it. But in a loving, nostailgic way. Future updates will provide more levels I assume.

As far as mechanics go, it's decently solid. There's an upgrade system, and a shop. You only keep your money and shop items until you die, but upgrades are permenant. Most controls aren't explained super well, but a quick look at the pause menu will give you all you need.

I decided to leave the things I didn't like for last, mostly because some if not all of them are likely to change.

-I'm not sure how keyboard/mouse controls are, so I would look into that if you don't have a controller.
-The game lags severely on my lower end machine. Going off of looks alone it shouldn't be lagging so bad. Either there's a LOT of computing going on or it's just unoptimized. Hopefully that gets better.
-Cars are too strong on early levels where you have weaker weapons. They force you off the road and while you can melee or shoot them, it takes a decent amount depending on the car. Especially police cars.
-Aiming mode camera needs to have an option to snapback to default


All in all it's a good damn game. You should check it out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state (ver 0.816) Road Redemption is a solid idea that very much needs some more time in the oven if it wants to earn the high pricetag the final version is said to be. The Road Rash roots are clear as day with high-speed motorcycle action fused with a combat system that has just the right amount of depth, but the execution doesn't feel quite right yet.

The game's Campaign modes offer a series of randomized challenges. During each session of a Campaign run, you'll earn money which you can use between stages to give yourself certain advantages for THAT PLAYTRHOUGH ONLY, such as doubling your money and temporary health boosts. Once you die you receive experience based on your performance to invest in another set of upgrades that are permanent and carry over into each new playthrough. The idea is solid and incentivizes you to keep going because with each run there's potential to better prepare yourself for the next run. It's a smart gameplay loop that's rewarding and fun to engage with.

The riding mechanics and combat are fairly easy to engage with. Riding has a very arcade-styled feel to it and it's relatively eas yto pick up and play. Combat has a surprising amount of depth, though it's still very possible to play thorugh the game never engaging with the advanced techniques like grabbing and deflecting attacks. The basics are here and they're very close to feeling complete. With a bit more polish, Road Redemption will be just as fun and engaging as its inspiration.

That said, the biggest issues Road Redemption faces right now are largely performance and balance related.  Depending on your setup, the game will either run like a dream or drop frames at an alarming rate when things get too hectic. This is obviously VERY bad for a game that can sometimes call for some tight precision in order to stay on your bike. The game's difficulty is all over the place, with a dynamic range of a bit too easy" to "completely unfair." Since all of the game's stages and objectives are randomly chosen
date: difficulty fluctuates wildly and it can only take VERY little for a good run to be a total wash in mere seconds. The rubberbanding of enemies feels a bit on the ridiculous side at the moment

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI expected the speed and the violence. On the store page, Road Redemption looks like a sort of Mario Kart meets Sons of Anarchy mash-up. What I was not prepared for was the extra depth of the rogue-like packaging it would come in. A single crash won't take you out of the race, but if your lifebar is drained, either by too many wipeouts or by other bikers, that's it. That campaign run is over and any winnings are left behind. Experience, however, which is accumulated over the course of the run, can only be used at its conclusion. That experience is used to purchase permanent perks which make your future bikers stronger and net you more money and/or more experience in future runs. After those perks are purchased, the experience total from that run is wiped away and you start from scratch, plus those permanent perks of course. The speed, the violence, and the adrenaline all make for an entertaining experience on their own, but past that, what really stuck me about Road Redemption is that I only started winning races once I noticed that the other cars on the road actually follow normal traffic patterns - as much as one can with motorcycles flying around every which-a-way of course. That means that the most obstacle-free places to travel, and thus the fastest, are the medians. You can jockey around cars as long as you understand that oncoming traffic needs to be avoided differently than the traffic you're following, but you'll only be able to relax and build speed safely once you've returned to a median. It's a surprisingly realistic situation for a game that revolves around swinging an ax or firing a grenade launcher from a speeding motorcycle.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In its current state (ver 0.816) Road Redemption is a solid idea that very much needs some more time in the oven if it wants to earn the high pricetag the final version is said to be. The Road Rash roots are clear as day with high-speed motorcycle action fused with a combat system that has just the right amount of depth, but the execution doesn't feel quite right yet.

The game's Campaign modes offer a series of randomized challenges. During each session of a Campaign run, you'll earn money which you can use between stages to give yourself certain advantages for THAT PLAYTRHOUGH ONLY, such as doubling your money and temporary health boosts. Once you die you receive experience based on your performance to invest in another set of upgrades that are permanent and carry over into each new playthrough. The idea is solid and incentivizes you to keep going because with each run there's potential to better prepare yourself for the next run. It's a smart gameplay loop that's rewarding and fun to engage with.

The riding mechanics and combat are fairly easy to engage with. Riding has a very arcade-styled feel to it and it's relatively eas yto pick up and play. Combat has a surprising amount of depth, though it's still very possible to play thorugh the game never engaging with the advanced techniques like grabbing and deflecting attacks. The basics are here and they're very close to feeling complete. With a bit more polish, Road Redemption will be just as fun and engaging as its inspiration.

That said, the biggest issues Road Redemption faces right now are largely performance and balance related.  Depending on your setup, the game will either run like a dream or drop frames at an alarming rate when things get too hectic. This is obviously VERY bad for a game that can sometimes call for some tight precision in order to stay on your bike. The game's difficulty is all over the place, with a dynamic range of a bit too easy" to "completely unfair." Since all of the game's stages and objectives are randomly chosen
date: difficulty fluctuates wildly and it can only take VERY little for a good run to be a total wash in mere seconds. The rubberbanding of enemies feels a bit on the ridiculous side at the moment

This game is AMAZING!

This game really shocked me, it looks like a standard arcade game, but after 20 minutes of playing this you realise it's insane fun. I do understand that it's only Early Access but my God I was shocked... I hope the developers add so much more to this...

Another little thing I loved about this was the fact it already supported Xbox 360 Controller support as I'd imagine using WASD would be a little awkward,,,

One thing I would've REALLY loved would have been allowing custom music tracks to the game but meh... Steam Overlay lets you now and you can mute the music from this game. (The music isn't bad... I rather listen to my stuff)

Finally, There is a few bugs to this game (Obviously, Early Access...) but none of them break the game and honestly, they made me laugh such as pinging off somewhere if crashing really hard and driving THROUGH rocks...

Things I'd personally change:
- On the mission where you need to get police attention, add multiple roads to choose to go down...
- At the end of the map, make the road into a tunnel instead of just end ( ruins the feel of the maps )
- On the Rooftop maps, Make the roof textures a little nicer, maybe a retexture...

Overall, This deserves 10/10... I know it's not complete yet but it can only get better and I have already fallen in love with this!..

Alright, so for the 65 minutes i've played of this game, i can say it is QUITE fun. Brings me back to my childhood, i remember playing this & my mum yelling at me because you could hit people. Oh nostalgia.. 10/10 for nostalgia points.

So all i can say is, if you have the money get it. 8/10, solid gameplay and controls but for the price it may be too expensive for the average gamer.
