reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before the review begins, i would like to note to everyone that i was given a copy of the game for free from the dev team to review, but this isnt a good review based on a contract. 'Road Redemption' dev team gave me, Angry Video Game Nerd, PewDiePie, Angry Joe and many many others early access to their game for free on the basis that they hope we give them a good review, BUT they did it in a much better way, you arent contracted to say good things, and they have given the game free to big game reviewers simply asking for their opinion. No strings attached, they need honest feedback. I have not been paid anything.

Thats the sign of a good listening dev team instead of ya know, the generic corrupt corperation. Doing it this way means that both the people are happy to recieve a free game and test it for them, and the dev team are happy to recieve the reviews and attention the game needs, that's PRO advertising right there. Contracts to give good reviews risks harming your company label when people reveal your corruption *cough EA cough﻿*

So firstly i would like to say Thank You devs for allowing me to check out your game!
This review is totally unbiast and simply my OWN opinion :)

--Basic Review--
As you may have already gotten from the Steam Videos, this game involves you riding around on a motorcycle in an infinitely generating world, where the track can take you anywhere from rooftops to the dusty deserts. Map generation is absolutely gorgeous as twisty hills and traps are generated all over the place, including hazardous traffic. Immidiately i was having flashbacks to an awesome game back on the Amiga and other consoles of my childhood, because as you, on your bike meet up with opponent racers with a 'Catch-Up' speed system, and knock them off their bikes with swinging a lead pipe to their faces...my childhood heart started pumping again as it felt like Road Rash was finally coming back to me, the game i had always wanted to be re-made.

The game is VERY familiar to Road Rash players, but it goes so much further than that, with the ability to ride an upgraded bike that can jump into the air with booster jets, and swing from helicopters with a hookshot. Even the Cars can sometimes be your greatest opponents in this game as they too, compete against you in many campaign missions.

Weaponry involves many melee weapons of different ranges and different strengths all the way to UZi submachine guns and grenade launchers, but here-in comes one of the greatest issues of the game at least as a PC user, KeyBoard and Mouse controls are VERY difficult to master as they become extremely twisty and you havent enough ability to drive, aim, attack, handbrake and all the rest at the same time. It is hard to play (but manageable) with a keyboard and mouse, but ultimately this is a game for a Controller. I Highly advise you grab a dual-analog controller and plug it in to maximize your control here. WASD is not very good at how sensitive you should steer your bike and you are going to need to drive with all of your skills here as the difficulty is quite high.

You will certainly get a blast out of this game, especially when the multiplayer module comes out, as PvP in this game is set to be one of the most fun things you have done in many years, all about the skill and not about the diceroll. The game is definitely worth your cash, but also a little patience as it is early access and of course, there are bugs and several things needed to be worked out.


--In Depth Review--
Graphics: 7/10
As you can imagine, worlds which are generated tend to look like they have been generated, rather than natural looking, but that's what makes the race tracks all the more fun than realistic, but the graphics in general are great with lovely lighting and shadows, incredible carcrash physics, lots of particles and bits of things flying everywhere, its great. There are however some major issues which lose the game some points here. There is always this kind of Dust Particle which approaches your screen at almost all times, which actually heats up the computer and in some cases, kills framerate even on powerful rigs like the one im running. Another issue is that large car crashes or great moments of vehicle damage causes the game's framerate to take a divebomb down to like 2 frames per second, which often forces you to kill the game and lose your progress. It's still early access so it's very easy to understand that this sorta thing will happen :)

Sound: 10/10
Countless games fall victim to a lack of sountrack, a lack of variation, and a lack of adrenaline and emotion to boot, but this game features a large playlist of music, each which will pump up your heart rate and convince you to keep driving and keep smacking people off their bike, the wonderful track lineup really keeps you playing the game so you can listen to them all. I hope in the future, like all games that have featured a kickass playlist (MAX Power Racing, Wipeout 2097 etc etc), will allow you to change track in the Pause menu, because i want to play my favorites over and over again! Maybe they could add buttons to utilize 'Next Track' and 'Previous Track' compatability. Weapons feel so realistic whenever you're in combat, from the sound of slapping meat to teeth-grinding chings of an iron weapon meeting someones skull, it sounds terrifyingly good. I have absolutely nothing to suggest when it comes to their sound lineup.

Gameplay: 6/10
It feels immidiately familiar to Road Rash players and brings back some well needed nostalgia, adding to what is an adrenaline filled game where every gut wrenching moment you fear for traffic over a hill knocking you off your bike, to battling a horde of cop cars and bikes, to avoiding the bullets and melee tools of an opponent biker and for the love of god keep your eyes on the road else you wont last long :D even the race track is twisty, bendy, requires sharp turns, and wants to kill you. It's very difficult doing all of this at once, but that's the beauty of this game and ones like it in the past, it NEEDS to be difficult and challenging...well it certainly is, sometimes feeling even unfair andd cruelly hard when actually sometimes there is nothing to do when you have been overwhelmed but try to stay alive. My only issue is that Police Cars are far too aggressive, where if a single police car hassles you from the beginning of a race, it is too easy and fast for that car to absolutely obliterate you and you dont always have a gun or powerful weapon to deal with it, making your entire race like trying to push or outrun Superman. As i have already mentioned, this game is hard, VERY hard, which is where i would like to suggest a Difficulty option, so that not-so-skilled players, or casuals can drive on easier tracks, with less aggressive AI and perhaps play a more casual and fun game.
There is a lack of Online multiplayer and game-modes right now, but give it some time as there already are plans to include them. It is very likely in the future, the 6 rating i have given, will turn into an 8 or 9 after it has been more developed on :)

Overall: 7/10   (after development you could even see up to 9/10)
You can tell the game is still early access with several bugs, cars suddenly driving on the incorrect lanes, particle and physical framerate slowdowns and ruthless Car AI, but after these are fixed and more game-modes are included, i would hope with a difficulty slider so people can play at their own pace and level, this game is definitely on it's way to being an instant classic, relivving old memories of games long forgotten but better. The development team are very generous, are listening to community feedback, and are hopefully working hard on this title, because Road Redemption if it continues on this path, is going to be a rolling success. It's just missing one thing, YOU.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Described as the spiritual sequel to Road Rash, Road Redemption is a fast paced motorbike riding katana wielding pile up of a wild ride. From zooming down motorways to leaping between rooftops the gameplay will definitely remind you of your days playing the old road rash series.

This time around however, there is no bike shop, and no story mode. The campaign is a series of randomly generated missions that give you cash which you can spend on items such as increased health or weapon damage. However, if you die while playing, you lose all your progress except for any experience gained. You can spend this experience on persistent upgrades such as improved health or bikes.

All in all a pretty enjoyable game especially considering that its still in early access. Its early access state is still obvious while playing however, everything has a work in progress feel. Fortunately the core gameplay is pretty well nailed down, so if they continue building the game around this it could be even better upon release.

The game also features 4 way split screen and controller compatibility, so local multiplayer is currently possible, and it looks like online multiplayer is on the horizon.

As with all early access games, only time will tell as to whether the finished product is worth your pennies, and in some cases, whether the game will actually be completed.

I would like to see the overall game modeled more after the N64 Road Rash but it is still fun. There needs to be rivals and biker gang issues. Earning small amounts of cash and slowly upgrading weapons/bikes. Keep hit damage lower to encourage more and longer battles. Road Redemption is at its best when you are flying down highways, making turns and battling. Overall this is a great start to a full version. If you aren't a fan of Road Rash then this alpha probably isn't for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I bought this game hoping for Road Rash. I was not disappointed.

At its core, Road Redemption has some extremely simple mechanics: Drive a motorcycle across some ridiculous procedurally generated terrain (the use of 'terrain' rather than 'roads' is definitely intentional) and beat other bikers with pipes and whatnot. If you liked Road Rash, this game will likely be right up your alley.

The procedurally generated 'tracks' are really well-done - they flow well, and they're varied enough to stay interesting. Let's be honest, it doesn't take a lot of track variety to make racing games work - many of them involve going around in circles for an hour, and that's fine. I was rather pleasantly surprised by how many little shortcuts and environmental quirks there were to find on these tracks.

There's missions to play through in a level-by-level system - each level presents some challenge... taking down other riders, winning a race, attracting the attention of the police, etc. You don't have to complete the challenge to pass the level, though doing so gets you some cash that you can spend on upgrades. These upgrades persist until you die, at which point you get a 'game over', and the next time you play, you're starting again from the beginning, but you also earn experience points which can be spent to buy persistent upgrades.

Each level is relatively short - 3-5 minutes, generally - so it's definitely an accessible game... you don't need hours of time to make it feel 'worth it' to play.

There's a wide range of weapons, including both melee (pipes, axes, maces, sticks, wrenches, etc.), ranged (pistols, rifles, harpoons, a grappling hook), and some special cases (dynomite, a grenade launcher, etc.), and they all have either ammo or durability. When you've run out of ammo or durability, the weapon is discarded. You can carry 3 or 4 with you, and they're very commonly obtained during the game (and sometimes between levels), so you don't feel like you have to be conservative, and you get to play with a wide variety of weapon types. In addition to the weapons, you have a kick and grab attack.

The riding physics are very arcadey in nature, but honestly, if you looked at the description for this game and expected a realistic biking sim, you might need professional help. You have fairly good air control when you take jumps (you can turn in mid-air), and crashing into a car, flying off your bike, skidding 200m on the pavement, then falling into a ravine does far less damage than being hit in the head with a pipe, but this is a good thing - it keeps the game fun.

There are some quirks, though. The physics can be a little weird in some cases, especially when going off the road is involved. The side-to-side collisions feel a little 'bouncy', and sometimes the camera angles can cause problems when you're in mid-crash and trying to recover.

I feel like the game could benefit greatly from a few other game modes, but I'm chalking the absence of such things up to it being early access. Some sort of 'endless' mode where you're just trying to see how long you can stay alive would be very fun, here.

The controls are very tight, especially if you use a controller.

The game is a little rough around the edges, but this seems more the result of it being an early access title than poor decision making on the developers' part.

Overall, I'd highly recommend this game if you enjoyed Road Rash or like similar arcade racing-combat games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'd recommend it for good fun, but as a huge fan of Road Rash N64, I read all the comments of everyone who was excited as their love for Road Rash was once again relived...buuut I soon found that this game is not as enjoyable as Road Rash (sorry gamers...).  I know this game is not Road Rash, but with the simularities, I assume they were headed for the same direction.  However, after palying this for a little while all it did was make me miss Road Rash.  So I'll do my review of the pros and cons:

Pros:
-Fun in it's own unique way as some moments from Road Rash are relived
-Traffic is certainly more active and makes for a fun ride
-Guns are an interesting, nice addition

Cons:
-The gameplay is too fast. You go all out in seconds and are forced to adapt to a very fast pace.  You get used to it after a awhile...sorta
-Riders spawn ahead of you.  You don't ride with a set group racing towards the finish (though there are some that remain...) but it's not as enjoyable when random riders keep coming (in my opinion)
-Not that many enviromental elements that you can explore.  Road Rash would have interesting little obsticles to ramp and get weapons or whatnot.  This version has you follow a road.  That's it. Sometimes adding a ramp in the road...but it's not as interesting (even the roof top levels aren't all that fun)

Altogether, I'm excited about the direction the game is taking and it's an early release so there is more to come...but I still prefer Road Rash 64 over this (thus far anyways).  I'd love it if someone remade Road Rash 64 with updated graphics and traffic.  This is not that game. Yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the first game that has actually prompted me to write a review on Steam, despite me being a member since 2004 and playing many great games on here! I loved Road Rash back in the day owning every version there was across the mega drive, 3do and PS1. I still think it is a disgrace the game was killed by EA and never saw a remake or sequel, a real missed opportunity, guess they can’t see past their endless versions of Fifa etc.

However, I am very pleased to report that road redemption captures that road rash magic and brings it into the modern world with aplomb. The racing is fast and fun with busy roads making just finishing alive a real challenge. Though it makes the game initially VERY difficult, the one life system does make the game more tense and challenging, adding a necessary sense of danger and a very real failure state. The combat is great fun and feels weighty and satisfying and it is addictive chaining kills and trying out all the different weapons. The guns are very good too but it is a bit disorientating when the camera moves with aiming, at least you can re-centre it (press right stick). And the C4 is just pure genius, that stuff never gets old!

However, whilst I adore this game already and think the developers are doing a great job, I do think the game still needs some work to be ready for release and there were a few things that puzzled me and things that just didn’t seem quite right, both in terms of design and the actual game engine.

The first ‘issue’ struck me quite early, I was driving alongside a police bike and hit a car and came off my bike, right I thought I’m ‘busted’ (as in road rash) but absolutely nothing happened, the police bike just went by. After extended play I realised the police bikes appear to be a different character and bike skin and nothing more. This is a huge missed opportunity IMO as the constant threat of being busted if you come off your bike was a major gameplay hook in road rash and could be here too.

Another thing, which isn’t a fault as such, but just felt weird compared to road rash was having cars (and sometimes even trucks etc) take part in the race. It just doesn’t seem a fair match and the way the cars in the race tend to slide from one side of the track to the other is distracting and just looks weird. I know the game is going for the arcade vibe but you can go too wildly unrealistic too, the cars shouldn’t be able to move like the bikes, they are much bigger and heavier.

There is sometimes just too much going on, too much carnage, too many cars, bikes, riders etc flying around. When these moments of pure carnage happened (particularly on the car rain tracks and the ones with explosives on the track) it kills performance (even on a pretty good PC) turning the game into a slideshow and making survival partly dependant on luck, which IMO is wrong, in a racing game like this it should always be skill, not luck that gets you through. Don’t get me wrong, avoiding a car landing on your head or some C4 is great fun, I’m not saying get rid of the car rain/explosives type levels, just make them a bit less frequent (or reduce their intensity a touch) and make the core (racing/brawling) gameplay the game’s main focus.  I’m just saying scale the whole destruction and wackiness thing back a bit, because the game doesn’t really need it, it can be enjoyable (and sometimes best) without it, road rash never had those things going on and never needed them either, the core mechanics of racing coupled with fighting is engaging enough.

The graphics are really impressive, especially for an early access title but there does seem to a bit of a lack of variety in scenery and locales (the rooftop tracks seem worst for this). Hopefully, the final release will see some more track types, the city levels in road rash with pedestrians, heavy traffic and tighter inner city roads were great and a nice green countryside type track with rolling fields and hills would really enhance the experience too.

As enjoyable as the career mode is, it currently is a bit short and lacks a real sense of progression from one event to the next, they get harder sure but with road rash the races actually got (much) longer too so aspects of survival (vs getting into a lot of fights) and trying not to come off the bike really started to play a part. I’d really like to see the races/events become bigger and longer as you move through the career mode giving the player a real sense of progression.

Lastly, in technical terms the game is superb for early access, no outright crashes at all. A few occasions on the roof top events when riding between the two buildings I fell down the middle of them, the game didn’t put me on the track (I was just stuck ‘in’ the building) using the option to reset back to track was tried several times but each time it just put me back in the middle of the gap between the buildings and I fell to my doom over and over until I ran out of energy. This only happened a few times but made me extra careful to time my jumps right!

Overall, sorry if this seems a negative review as I think the game is great already and seeing a road rash homage is a personal dream come true. I would recommend it highly as it is right now, I just really want to see the final release be as good as it possibly can be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Remember Road Rash? Kind of? Okay, that’s good enough. The homicidal motorcycle racing genre never went stale. Instead, it kind of never went anywhere. Those games died on the side of some infinite stretch of desolate highway in the late ‘90s. Luckily, the people at DarkSeas flipped open their Necronomicon and decided to revive the genre with Road Redemption and I couldn’t be happier. It’s at least ten times the skull busting, engine revving, cap popping, and jump jetting you can remember.

Set in a world where cars can, and occasionally will, rain from the sky, this is the Road Rashiest rehash you could possibly envision. Calling it a tribute doesn’t even do it justice. Road Redemption does more for this niche racing genre than any game before it. It’s nearly perfect and, technically, not even a finished product. Part roguelike, part RPG, and all high-octane violence, this game is both incredibly easy to get into and difficult to perfect. Careen across skyscrapers and swerve around crumbled competition – there are a ton of surprises folded into this title. Pure entertainment and a “must own” for old-school fans.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hard to say whether the game is good or not. Reviving the epic Road Rash is a great idea, but for people like me who are nostalgic to the childhood memory may feel a bit disappointed. As long as I remember, one of the best thing about Road Rash is the unlimited freedom it gives to the player, e.g. you can simply drop you motor and run all the way the finish line, however the freedom is absent from Road Redemption.

First the new game runs in a much faster pace with much shorter tracks, which leaves the players busily doging coming veichles and runs like hell to the finish line, no time is left for more fun. Secondly the player dies far too easily: either you get hit by a car coming into your face (waaaay too much traffic!), or a car dropped randomly from the sky, or simply got slashed by a axe two times. I would still stick to the idea that you could pick up your bike and ride on when you got seriously damaged. Then it is the optimization issue. The game is supposed to be affordable even for mid tier laptops, but with a brand new MSI with a GeForce 970M GPU I still experience some significant PFS drop. Finally, is it really neccessary to have some troll events like Hallucinogen*****, or to let the player compete with a car? I have already have Goat Simulator so I truly don't need another game just like that, especially for a game that I wish I could invest more time in.

For the pros, the game has some really good level designs, for which I mean level 4 where you can compete on the rooftop with a jet pack on your rear wheel. I did not get to all the campaign levels but I believe there will be more surprise to come.

To note that this is an alpha version so there is still a lot that can be improved. With a fantastic initial concept I am hoping for future updates. So with my expectation high on this I will give it a yes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRoad Redemption is basically the spiritual sequel to the old Road Rash games. The rooftop levels are sometimes a little overkill (i.e., I'd rather race and beat up other racers than worry about grappling around like Spiderman), but overall a fun game, and most of the levels and challenges are engaging and entertaining. In my experience, playing with a controller is MUCH better than with keyboard, which is a swich, since I'm normally a keyboard & mouse gamer. However, the responsiveness in turning and braking seems easier to control via controller. Ultimately, I think it's been worth the purchase and I'm looking forward to seeing the finished results of the completed game (currently playing in Early Access).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr at bottom
I plan on continually updating this review based on whether or not anyone has any questions (ask through Steam or comments), and if people find it informative. So, please rate up if you think this is helpful in any way. :)

I'm putting this sentiment as the foremost part of the review, because I feel it's what most gamers can relate to, and is an accurate summary of the game:
Remember the adrenaline filled moments of speeding down the city streets of Just Cause 2, or even Grand Theft Auto, watching the high-speed collisions around you as the cars of would-be-driver corpses explode into oncoming traffic? Imagine that, but completely revamped and overhauled into the most action packed, brutal street racing game you can imagine. That is precisely what Road Redemption is.

Basically, the core of this game is, slipping around through traffic and other racers, while also attempting to maintain your speed, while, on top of that, trying to dispatch aforementioned 'other racers.' All of this, of course, is extremely well executed, and it was difficult for me to convince myself I should stop playing so I can write this review and go to sleep.

To start, the controls are relatively simple, and effective, as most games' are. I can't say much here, as they are pretty average, and you shouldn't have an issue. I found most of the mechanics to work pretty smoothly, and had no grievances.

The gameplay is fantastic. Weaving through traffic, popping people with anything from a shovel to C4, trying to line up with ramps without getting killed by a madman with a baseball bat (all in good fun, of course). The only mentionable complaints I have are that, it can get a bit frustrating or repetitive if you manage to die a bit too many times over, but if you aren't a complete psychopath, making it your goal to kill everyone in sight, it shouldn't be too much of an issue.

The graphics are on par with modern standards, making it easy to run, and pretty enough to look at. It's no Crysis, but I'm certainly not complaining. The real focus here is the intense slaughter-ifying.

tl;dr
Pros
+ Gets updated (can't say the same for many early access games).
+ Fast paced (assuming you like it that way).
+ Satisfying campaign length. Lots of hours in it.
+ Satisfying map variety.
+ Easy to run.
+ Fair graphics/visuals.
+ Explosions.
+ Very rewarding.
+ User friendly.
+ Multiplayer
+ Coop

Cons
- Mild repetitivity. Not enough to stop your from playing.
- Weapon repetitivity. There is melee and guns, that's about as advanced as it gets.
- Occasional lag spikes, notably on hallucinogenic" levels.
- AI are predictable
date: and somewhat simple (though they are still very fun).\n- Can be frustrating
recommended: despite the satisfaction of progressing.\n\nOnce again
hoursPlayed: I would gladly answer any questions
voteText: so either comment or ask me through Steam if you have any. Also

votesHelpful: so I know whether I should continue updating it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Previously I gave this game a 'no' review. There have been some changes that have made the game playable and even enjoyable. The physics of the bike in the air is ridiculous... but then again so is the whole idea of the game. There is some satisfaction to be had in planting a bomb on a rival gang member's bike or grappling them until they are hit by an on-coming car. Then there's the 'cars raining from the sky' which isn't a bug but an actual developers' choice for a thing to be happening while you are trying to dodge cars and bikers.

The biggest issue at the moment on my system is that the game crashes out when trying to load levels. This appears to be due to the game using up all available memory and can be delayed by setting it at the the graphics to 'fastest'. The developers are aware of this and are trying to sort it out.

As this game has no plot it can be very satisfying to just jump in a race, smash of few bikers down and then walk away. The weapons have different characteristics and learning to time the strikes is interesting.

I wouldn't say the game is worth $20 in its current state but, with the effort being put in to fix the errors, I would say that it will be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome Game!!!  If you enjoyed the Road Rash series of games in your youth, or if you think you would enjoy motorcycle combat then i highly suggest you check this game out.  Yes its in early access but that doesn't mean it isn't a quality game.  I hope to see more story line in game.  Maybe a little more backstory.

I gotta say its very satisfying playing the game.  I use gamepads basically for any games, and the controls are solid.

I had one mission where i had a bunch of c4 at the beginning of a master race, and basically destroyed everyone right off the bat, it was very sweet!

My only complaint is that some of the music feels a little weak, and one map its rather odd(you will know it when you hear it)  A great fix for that would be if we could have our own music in game maybe?  I don't know how complicated that would be though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is one recipe for FUN! If you ever enjoyed playing Road Rash, then this game is definitely for you. Personally, I can't wait for the full release.

Note for developers: This game has minor issues, otherwise it has every potential to be a true masterpiece of its kind:

1. Add more tracks, make them more interactive, comfortably beautiful for the eyes, deep and stunts friendly. As this game is about motorcycles, someone should expect to do some sightseeing not only 'playing'.
2. The camera control can be much better if you add native view angles.
3. Add gangs. Make it possible for players to create their own gangs and to make them their own.
4. MAKE THE GAME MORE INSANE!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I personally liked this game, even though it still an early acess, with a lot of future features left aside, but as for now, I liked the game as a whole, except for:

-Jet fuel rocket pack... Seriously?
-Harpoon... Yes. There is a grapling gun... For your bike.
-Rooftops track. This one is not so bad if you get used to it, but the idea is a bit surreal.
-Snow track is not challenging at all. It's frustrating because of all the random cars moving everywhere.
-Hallucinogenic race mutator. More or less on the level of snow and random cars out of nowhere.
-(CAREFULL! Spoiler... DO NOT READ): Mario cart track at the end. Seriosly?

I'd say, 9/10, but it's more of a 9/11 with all that jet fuel and metal beams.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nRoad Redemption is basically the spiritual sequel to the old Road Rash games. The rooftop levels are sometimes a little overkill (i.e., I'd rather race and beat up other racers than worry about grappling around like Spiderman), but overall a fun game, and most of the levels and challenges are engaging and entertaining. In my experience, playing with a controller is MUCH better than with keyboard, which is a swich, since I'm normally a keyboard & mouse gamer. However, the responsiveness in turning and braking seems easier to control via controller. Ultimately, I think it's been worth the purchase and I'm looking forward to seeing the finished results of the completed game (currently playing in Early Access).

As it's still Early Access and the game feels already great, I give it the benefit of the doubt. Although, I feel it's not worth 20€ at the moment, so get it at a sale or at a later stage of development.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

potential biker gang wars online here.

My only concern is the overpowered nature of firearms that could potentially pose online PVP balance issues. The classic road rash games never had guns. it was melee only. I suggest being stingy with ammo in PVP. Even still there is an interesting balance hurdle here. If you steer with keyboard WASD, you'll have the typical non ideal stiff WASD driving controlls but the trade off is your fireaim Aim will be massively OP with the mouse... but if you use a controller, your steering will be better than the keyboard but the tradeoff is your Aim with guns will be awful via thumb stick aim @ PCmaster race keyboard+mouse=superior aim  @ controllers suck for aiming crosshairs in anyway shape or form.  I for 1 would much rather use a keyboard and mouse but steer poorly via WASD because the guns are just too good of a trade off. It's just much simpler to drive stiff with WASD but then blow everybody away with guns as opposed to trying to race them traditionally... and is that really the route they wanna go down in what's ultimately a driving game.. aim and shooting being more important than driving? Something like www.aimpad.com (assuming it comes out) would give somebody a massive unfair pay to win multiplayer advantage.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excelente jogo. Nostálgico. Joguei com meu primo a campanha e a campanha+ com manetes e foi muito bom. Recomendo a compra. Muito bacana dar uma cacetada nas costas dele ou tomar aquele bico inesperado na ponte, lembrando que era coop.

O que ficou faltando???
1)Chefes estilo MadMax
2)Coquetel molotov
3)Rook/Arpão
3)Modo VIP (NPCs protegem um cara de terno e gravata que se você agarrar vai pra sua garupa)
4)Gente na Garupa/Companion(mulher que te cura; maluco barbudo que te defende; cientista bufando os stats da moto...)
5)Workshop

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


Excellent game. Nostalgic. I played with my cousin the campaign and the campaign + with controllers and it was very good. I recommend buying. It was very cool to hit his back or take the unexpected kick on the bridge, remembering that was coop.

What was missing ???
1) Bosses MadMax-style
2) Molotov cocktail
3) Rook / Harpoon
3) VIP mode (NPCs protect a suit and tie guy whose you have to grab for your rump)
4) Companions (woman who heals you, crazy bearded defender, scientist snorting the stats of the bike ...)
5) Workshop

reviewerDisplayName: Grand Dad the guy or something
reviewText:
Early Access Review

Road Redemption. Holy crap, this game is absolutely AMAZING. It's so fun and addictive that I had to keep coming back to it everyday! I love the feeling when you smash a baseball bat straight in someones face, or when you launch them sky high with a Sticky Bomb or Grenade Launcher.

I've never played Road Rash, but I will say that you do not need to play that game to enjoy this. I had a great time shooting people off their bikes while flying in the air on rooftops while zip lining from helicopter to helicopter. All the different areas are long and very entertaining, especially when you're destroying everything in sight.

This game however, can be difficult. Car storms are challenging, fun and frustrating to drive through, while crazy traffic causes mass mayhem and destruction, but it doesn't stop there. Once you beat the normal Campaign (1-3 hours depending on how good you are) you unlock Campaign+ and holy crap, it's hard.

The Gameplay overall is awesome, fun, challenging and sometimes aggravating. It will keep you entertained for sometime. The great thing about this is, even though there's only about 3-7 Hours of play, the game is has a lot of replay-ability, with having almost all the levels different each time, with a leveling up system that works pretty nice. Plus, the game is still being developed with a competitive mode in development!

Now for the look of the game, the graphics are really good. The texture quality could be improved a bit, and there should be a bit more optimizations rather than the normal Unity start up menu,  but that's just something I'd prefer.
The Shadow quality is pretty good as well, but it could be improved upon a bit as well.

Overall, a great game with great graphics, great gameplay and lots of replay-ability. A must have for all those people who love destruction and fast paced gameplay.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a difficult one for me. I love the days of Road Rash, was one of my favourite games growing up, and there's a lot to like about Road Redemption in comparison with it. Weapon variety is great, and the arcadey feel is in the ballpark of what I was hoping for.

However, this game is very much early access. The content seems rather shallow and limited, it doesn't do a couple of big things which I considered great from the classic Road Rash games... which I hope will change as development goes on. Buggy as anything as well of course, and I'll forgive a lot of it (too easy to get stuck behind objects, I know there's the option in the menu to put you back on the track, but having it on the controller would make more sense) but the big down for me is that it crashed 3 times within just over an hours play. That's bad, even for an early access game (especially one which has been around for a fair bit).

I'd like to say I recommend the game, but as it stands I can't. Of course, things will change as the game gets closer to release, and it's not one I've given up on either... there's enough fun there at its core that with a lot of work it will become more playable as time goes on.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I am going to give a honnest review, and update my review as I play the game. How can this game become the best it can be if I hide it's flaws? Even though this game was given to me by the Dev I can not use that for this review, and hope the overwelmingly positive reviews are not positive because it was given free to them.

I surpass the minimum and recomended specs yet playing on the Fast game settings, the quailty is really poor and the framerate is around 10ish frames intermitant and not smooth, really shuttering. Gonna try Fastest next time. No multiplayer that I could find first play. I find the no gun weapons to be quiet hard to use. This is not a racing game it is like a deathmatch game, but this is nothing like Twisted Metal. The gameplay reminds me of another game on a console I used to play where you could hit people off, but in that game you are racing. The controls are ok, yet trying to shoot behind you and drive is hard. It is easier to shoot behind while driving in GTA.

The gameplay is ok, I do enjoy going off road, and the ragdoll. but it just is unplayable with the framerate issues. I find it impossible to hit the ramps, yet it seems like I am driving stright into poles pretty easy.

Music is great, so are the sounds.

Will play more and reupdate and hope this game improves.

Update 1: Switched to Fastest and Set Launch Options to -dxlevel 80 longer bursts of good frames but still have periods of bad bad frames and pauses. A lot more fun to actually be destructive for once. Can't wait till they optimize it and make it to where it does not shutter or stall/pause!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Badly developed, and no thought put into the campaign.  You just pick some random rider on a random bike; rather than being in a gang, progressing through the street races, buying better equipment etc etc, so you feel completely disinterested in the whole game really.  Not to mention there are no saves, so once you are dead - you are dead.

Worst of all though - the races are very boring and only last about 3 mins.  They also have this ridiculous 'knock off other riders in the time limit' rather than races, which gets old even the second time around.

Hard to wreck a classic game concept, as they couldn't have butchered this game any more in they had of tried.  Not a scratch on Road Rash; so do yourself a favour and go and get a PS1 emulator instead of this crap.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was not exactly expecting much when offered to beta test a game by someone with the same name as the game.  After idling for cards one day, I forgot about the game entirely for a month or two.

Then I felt guilty and decided to fire it up, figuring I would quit after 30 seconds and move on.

I did not expect to get sucked in immediately.  Particularly as I have not liked a racing game since the early 1990s.

This game is a great balance of absurdist action fun and enjoyable racing; even trying to do something as simple as watching for cars barrelling straight at you while you also try to maneuver into the perfect position to club a nearby racer to death proves excellently challenging.

But what really seals the deal of this being a game worth playing is the reward system--receiving cash at the end of every race that you can use for temporary upgrades, and then experience upon death (based on your successes in the races) that can be used for permanent upgrades, is a pretty addictive system.  It certainly kept me playing longer than I expected, and I found myself planning out my next upgrades without even realizing it.

So, overall, a racing game worth playing for people who hate racing games--probably even for people who love racing games!
